TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the latest plans of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for wage increases to be based on anticipated increases in the consumer price index. I refer also to the fact that Australia's unit labour costs are growing at more than double the average rate of our major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners, thereby obviously eroding our competitiveness. In view of the relatively poor productivity performance in Australia, I ask the Minister whether the ACTU's plan would bring about a reduction in the rate of growth of unit labour costs to that of our trading partners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironic that a question of this nature comes from a person who was a Minister in the previous Government which, in its last year in office, had a rate of increase of wages 10 per cent higher than that of our trading partners. Under this Government there has been no such disparity. The fact is that the wages system that is being pursued by the present Government is one which, by any standards, has been a fair but tough policy and one which has resulted in a reduction in real wages which has been sought, by the way in which that has happened, to protect the lower paid workers as much as possible. Nevertheless, across the spectrum of wage and salary earners it has resulted in a substantial reduction in real wages.

ANSWER.PARA: In the process of that happening, in the last year or two there has been a higher rate of wage increase than in that of our trading partners. With the severe devaluation of the Australian dollar our price levels were inevitably pushed up. In those circumstances, if we were to have a rate of wage increase at the level of our trading partners, we either had to have a much greater reduction in real wages, which is presumably what the Opposition wants to see happen, or we had to have a system which was a bit balanced and which met the need for reductions in real wages while seeking, so far as was possible and was economically responsible, to protect the living standards of wage and salary earners.

That has been the policy that we have pursued. That policy encompasses the approach that we will seek to bring the rate of increase of Australian wages closer to that of our trading partners. As the inflation rate comes down, as is now occurring, that becomes more possible. Also, in terms of ensuring that our competitiveness is maintained, we are taking various steps to ensure that productivity is increased. For the first time in our history as a nation the wages system has been put on a basis where, as part and parcel of receiving a wage increase, there is a requirement for increased productivity or improved efficiency. The whole second tier element is based on that. Of course, there have been considerable delays in many people getting a second tier increase because of the need to negotiate and to work out ways in which productivity and efficiency could be improved. As that system moves into place we can expect that productivity will increase as a result of that action. We would expect-indeed it will remain our policy-the wages system to continue to evolve. Doubtless it will change somewhat from what it is at present, but in our view an element of increasing productivity and efficiency will be retained as a key part of that wages policy.

The ACTU has made its position broadly known. The Government will be having discussions with the ACTU, with the Confederation of Australian Industry and with the Business Council of Australia in the near future as we move towards the May review and we will make our position absolutely clear on the wages system in the future. But let me give this absolute assurance to the House: It remains our policy to try to bring the rate of growth in wages and the unit labour costs in Australia as close to our trading partners' as we possibly can. That involves not only consideration of wage increases but also consideration of productivity improvement. On both counts the Government is taking the right approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In the light of the rally held today outside Parliament by the Australian Pensioners Federation can the Minister inform the House of how Labor's achievements in government have provided help for the aged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I think the present Government can be proud of its record in terms of maintaining the real income of pensioners during a time of economic restraint and during a time in which the country has faced quite severe economic difficulties. The annual cost of maintaining the indexation of pensions is around $1 billion a year and I think one has to recognise the magnitude of the achievement which has seen an increase of around $40 to the pension since 1983. Of course, 65 per cent of the social security budget is paid to pensioners who are aged, are invalids or are widows. We have to contrast the relative security under which pensioners live because of the policy of the present Government with the massive insecurity that they would face under alternative economic policies. Only a few months ago the Leader of the Opposition was talking about the need for $11 billion worth of cuts. When he talks about that level of cuts he is careful not to alienate anyone. Indeed, the hallmark of this irresponsible Opposition is that it is prepared to criticise, to groan and to weep about what the Government may be doing. It is not prepared to be specific in terms of its own policies but it throws out that kind of figure which must represent a threat to the potential living standards of every Australian pensioner.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that the strongest plank in this Government's platform has been the maintenance of the income of the elderly and retired people on low and fixed incomes. In 1983 the Prime Minister promised that we would achieve 25 per cent of average weekly earnings-that is, we would maintain and improve the relationship between the living standards of pensioners vis-a-vis the wage earning population. We have virtually achieved that standard. There has been an 8.2 per cent real increase in the rate of pensions in the period we have been in government. That compares with a situation when we came into office where the pension was as low as 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings or pensions had dropped in real terms by 2.4 per cent.

To be in government is always to be placed in a situation where there are difficult decisions to make. It is a mark of the responsibility of the present Government that, despite all the difficult decisions that have been made, we have maintained and improved the real living standards of age pensioners in Australia. It is a mark of the irresponsibility of the Opposition that, when it was in government, it reduced the living standards of those people and, in opposition, it promised airily to cut $11 billion while at the same time it said to people such as the pensioners outside, `You do not need to worry about us. We will find $11 billion from somewhere else'. No one really believes that. People know that this Government has been marked by fairness and equity and they know that ultimately, whenever the Opposition is confronted with a tough decision, it will run away from that decision, particularly when its friends want their business lunches and when its friends who have assets of more than $1m want pensions. Those people will be protected by the Opposition and the living standards of the age pensioners will be chopped into.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MDA GRAMMAR SCHOOL, VICTORIA: COMPLAINTS BY OVERSEAS STUDENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of complaints made by Hong Kong students who have paid full fees to attend the MDA Grammar School in Victoria? If so, can the Minister inform the House of the nature of those complaints, what implications this incident may have for Australia's full fee program for overseas students and what action the Government has taken in relation to this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of complaints that have been made, particularly through our consulate in Hong Kong, in respect of students attending the MDA Grammar School in Victoria. About 60 of the 100 students from Hong Kong at the school have formally registered complaints with us. The complaints fall into a number of categories. First of all, there is concern about the marketing practices of MDA and its agents in Hong Kong. Specific allegations relate to misrepresentation on matters such as fees and facilities. Secondly, there have been complaints about the school facilities. Accommodation arrangements have been unsatisfactory and the intensive English language program in particular did not meet students' expectations and had not been properly accredited. Other matters relating to the welfare and treatment of students are also of concern to the people making the complaints.

ANSWER.PARA: A report by my Department, which I instigated, has confirmed the validity of many of these complaints. But I want to emphasise that this is just a one-off incident in what has been a very successful program of offering full fee courses in Australia to overseas students. This has been a rapidly growing program and it is perhaps not surprising that there have been some teething problems of this kind. However, the Government is determined to ensure that this incident will not be allowed to tarnish the high reputation that Australia has developed for its education system, particularly in Hong Kong from where the greatest number of students coming to Australia originate.

The welfare of the students affected has been immediately addressed. My Department has been instructed to facilitate the transfer of students to other schools where this is requested by the student with parental consent. Members of the Melbourne community have assisted by offering alternative accommodation, help in transferring to new schools and counselling on legal rights. The Government is co-operating with Victorian authorities in examining the operations of the school. For the time being, the school has been suspended from offering places to overseas students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Have all compensation claims received by the Parliament House Construction Authority (PHCA) associated with the banning of rainforest timber from north Queensland now been received and assessed? Does the Minister still assert that the value of these claims is $500,000? What has been the additional cost to the Parliament House Construction Authority of the Commonwealth ban on Queensland rainforest timbers? Finally, could the Minister advise whether or not the timber used in construction as an alternative to the Queensland timber was supplied locally or was imported?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I present the thirteenth report of the Parliament House Construction Authority sometime within the next six weeks, we should be in a position to give the full cost of the decision not to use rainforest timber in the new Parliament House. The question of whether or not we should use rainforest timber in the new Parliament House was discussed some months ago and there are a number of misconceptions around relating to the decision that was taken. The Parliament House Construction Authority, in recognition of its obligations under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, required those seeking to use timber felled from heritage areas after 6 March 1986 to seek prior and written approval from the PHCA. No approvals have been sought or given in that regard.

ANSWER.PARA: We announced the intention of nominating the wet tropics area of north Queensland for World Heritage listing. As a result, at that time a north Queensland company placed bans on the delivery of rainforest timbers ready for shipment to manufacturers of furniture for the new Parliament House. Also the main construction company would not give assurances that the timber had not been felled after 6 March 1986 in accordance with the contract in relation to areas excluded by the PHCA's timber agreements.

At that time the Authority and I had to discuss the situation. Companies which had a contract to supply something like 40 per cent of the timber for the furniture were simply refusing to supply to score a political point. Obviously we could not continue to tolerate that situation. At any rate, the contracts stipulated that the timber ought not to come from national heritage areas. I know that the Authority, after discussion with me, sought assurances from the main contractor concerned that the timber in fact did not come from areas which were stipulated in the contract as not being acceptable. At that point we certainly had to take a decision on whether or not the whole series of contracts for the provision of furniture would be delayed or not. So we assessed the situation and took an overall decision that in fact we would not take the timber anyway and, furthermore, that we would not accept any rainforest timber that was not in the hands of the manufacturers after a date early in August.

That was a tough decision to take. We had to take it. We had a position where this Government had legitimately decided to nominate the wet tropics of Queensland for World Heritage listing. We had contracts which stipulated that the timber was not to come from areas that had been listed by the National Heritage Commission. We could not get the assurances on supply source from the companies concerned which were to supply something like 40 per cent of the timber. So we were faced with having to make a decision about what to do. We took the tough decision, in effect to cut our losses and to get out. The question of how much that decision will cost will be reported in due course. However, in the main, the timber for the furniture in the new Parliament House will be local and imports will be minimised-in fact, I do not think that any imported timber will be used at all in the new Parliament House furniture.

Finally, the figures that have been bandied about in the newspapers as to the cost of this decision being around $15m are simply wildly exaggerated and I doubt whether the final figure, when it is determined, will exceed $900,000. In fact, it should be less. We had deadlines to meet and, as the Minister, I would not tolerate a company in north Queensland attempting to stand over this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Defence been drawn to claims that the Australian Defence Force is bored and underutilised and should be used to back up Australia's foreign policy objectives? If so, is the Australian Defence Force bored? Are members of the Defence Force given opportunities to serve abroad? Does the Australian Defence Force contribute to developing better relations with our regional neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Herbert could probably answer his question better than I can because of the contact he has with servicemen in his area. I have seen the Opposition's claims to the effect that it believes that members of the Australian Defence Force are bored and that it would be quite useful to use them overseas to overcome that boredom. However, my impression of our servicemen is that they are not bored and that they are now very highly geared to developing doctrine and tactics associated with the White Paper strategies of defence self-reliance. Indeed, while many of them are preoccupied this year with bicentennial activities, they are working up to extremely big exercises next year in Kangaroo 89, which will exercise the capabilities of our defence forces, particularly our ground forces, right across northern Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from those activities, members of the Australian Defence Force are intensively and increasingly involved in activities overseas associated with the defence co-operation program (DCP). In fact, each year some 1,300 members of the Australian Defence Force travel abroad for combined exercises and 500 are overseas on long term training and exchange programs or DCP projects. That is quite a sizeable proportion of them. In addition, 122 visits were made by the Royal Australian Navy to 16 countries last year. I think the evidence of our experience last year should suggest to all honourable members that, where we define it as being in our national interests and where we seek either to advance these interests or our relations with other countries, this Government is not at all loath to use our military forces appropriately. But we will use them overseas in connection with the national interest; we will not send them there just because we believe them to be bored.

—I certainly share with the honourable member for Robertson the pride that he properly has in the quality of the Australian film industry. I think that it has been one of the great developments of Australia over recent years-and not simply in the last five years; this is something which has occurred over a longer period. All of us take pride in that. I assure the honourable gentleman that I have noticed the reference to the meetings that have recently been held on this matter and the concern that has been expressed. At this point I am not aware of any representations that have been made to Government. I am not saying that they have not been made. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. As I understand it, the honourable member for Flinders is speaking to a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. On the one hand, we have Senator Tate and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying that in their view nothing in the material that has not been made public conflicts with the substance of the answer given by Senator Tate, although Senator Tate, be it remembered without dispute, is on record as admitting that he misled the Parliament. On the other hand, we have the interpretation of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the shadow Attorney-General, to the effect that so far from his examination of material supporting the interpretation of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that there is no conflict between the unpublished material and the answer given in the Senate, there is a conflict. SPEECH.PARA: Is it not a supreme exercise in commonsense that that material be made public and that this House and the Australian public have an opportunity to make a decision as to whether the interpretation arrived at by Senator Tate and the Prime Minister is to be preferred or whether the interpretation arrived at by the honourable member for Flinders is to be preferred? It ought to be remembered by honourable members opposite that this issue is back before us today because of a bungled attempt by their Prime Minister to cloud the issue. In the process, all that the Prime Minister has done is deepen the suspicion on the part of the Opposition that the Government has something to hide. If ever we have seen an exercise in prime ministerial bungling, we have seen one today because, far from resolving doubts about the issue, all that the Prime Minister has done is to parade in stark form his sensitivity about the issue. I say to the Prime Minister, I say to Senator Tate, I say to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and I say to members of the Government: What do you have to hide? If it is the judgment of this Parliament that the version of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Justice is to be believed, that will be the end of the matter, but until such time as they can back their statements with facts, we will continue to pursue this matter. The only way it can be resolved and the cloud over Senator Tate's head removed is for the Prime Minister to have the courage of his assertions. He should come in here, table the documents and let the public and the Australian Parliament determine the matter for themselves.

—I recall some excellent speeches on exactly that sort of subject by the honourable member who is interjecting. PROCTEXT.PARA: Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Bill
Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to remove an inequity in the imposition of levy on dairy products and to streamline the administration by the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) of the dairy product levy system. The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986-the Act-provides for the imposition of levy on dairy products that have been produced at a factory on or after 1 July 1986. The levy is payable by dairy manufacturers upon the sale of specified dairy products, currently butter and cheese, to fund supplementary market support of the dairy product export sector over and above the primary market support funded by the all milk levy. As the levy is intended to support domestic prices, a person who exports butter or cheese may seek an exemption from payment of the levy. Subject to certain limitations these arrangements also apply to butter and cheese contained in mixtures which are exported. Exemptions are issued by the ADC.

The arrangements reflect those which operated under the old dairy arrangements, the stabilisation levy on major dairy products operating prior to 1 July 1986-where consignments of mixtures for export under 15 tonnes weight, one container load, and mixtures with less than 25 per cent dairy product content were not eligible for exemption. The intention of these limits was to avoid the need to process small consignments, or consignments involving only minimal dairy product content, which would involve disproportionately high administrative costs with little benefit to the exporter.

When the new arrangements commenced, in order to be consistent with the market support element the limit on refund of levy relating to minimum percentage of leviable product in mixtures, as set down in sub-section 9 (3) and prescribed in sub-section 9 (4) of the Act, was reduced to one per cent. However, the minimum weight of 15 tonnes per consignment was retained through sub-sections 9 (3) and 9 (4) of the Act as it was thought that the administrative costs relating to applications for consignments of less than one container load would be prohibitive. The ADC has since indicated that, in fact, the cost of administering the minimum weight limit outweighs the benefit derived from the exclusion. In addition, the limit discriminates against a manufacturer who exports a large amount of butter or cheese in a small consignment compared with one who exports small amounts in large consignments.

The Government has decided to accept the ADC recommendations that the situation be remedied by deleting sub-sections 9 (3) and 9 (4) of the Act to eliminate the weight and dairy produce content constraints. The result will be that any amount of butter and cheese exported in a mixture will qualify for levy exemption.

The amendment will apply from 1 July 1986 to put all applicants on an equal basis from the commencement of the new dairy marketing arrangements. Retrospectivity will also validate some exemptions which the ADC has already given but which would on a strict interpretation be inconsistent with the existing provisions of sub-sections 9 (3) and 9 (4) although not inconsistent with the intention of this amendment. The amendment will result in savings in administration costs to the Australian Dairy Corporation and hence to the dairy industry at large and it will place the payment of levy on dairy products on a more equitable basis. It will have no financial implications for the Commonwealth. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 to remove limitations on the imposition of charge for export inspection services performed outside export registered establishments. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 is one of three Acts introduced by the Government to give as much flexibility as possible in determining appropriate export inspection charging systems for different sectors of the primary produce export industry-the other Acts are the Export Inspection (Quantity Charge) Act 1985 and the Export Inspection (Establishment Registration Charges) Act 1985.

At the time the Act was introduced most export inspection was carried out in establishments that were registered for the preparation of goods for export. Increasingly, export inspection services are being performed at places outside export registered establishments in response to requests by persons who are not occupiers of registered establishments. In many cases inspection is not for the purpose of enforcing Australian export controls but to facilitate exports by providing certification required by the importing country.

The registration of these places would be wasteful and would place an unnecessary burden on industry. Consequently the Government believes further flexibility is needed to permit effective cost recovery for these services while ensuring that industry is not burdened with unnecessary legislative requirements. The Bill amends those provisions of the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 which prevent the imposition of charge for export inspection services provided in places which are not registered export establishments.

The Bill will have only a minor financial impact, as any charge imposed will in the main replace cost recovery measures that currently apply. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: DIPLOMATIC AND CONSULAR PRIVILEGES AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Duffy, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUFFY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade Negotiations and Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend both the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967 and the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972 which give legislative effect to the provisions of the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations and the 1963 Vienna Convention on Consular Relations respectively.

The Bill provides that tax imposed under any of the various sales tax Acts is not payable in respect of goods intended for the official use, and not resale, of a diplomatic mission or consular post of a prescribed overseas country provided the goods are purchased from a registered sales tax payer.

These amendments have become necessary due to increasing criticism which Australia has received in relation to our interpretation of particular provisions of the two Vienna Conventions. Under those conventions the personnel at foreign missions and posts are exempt from direct taxes but must pay indirect taxes of a kind which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services. The Government has consistently maintained that the Australian sales tax system is, due to its manner of operation, an indirect tax and as such is payable by foreign missions and posts. However, the Government also takes the view that the sales tax and value added tax systems operated by the United States of America and certain western European countries are direct taxes from which Australian personnel are exempt. This interpretation has been disputed and on a number of occasions other countries have sought to collect sales and value added tax not only from Australian personnel but also from missions and posts. In order to maintain our exemption overseas it may, therefore, be necessary while maintaining our interpretation of the Conventions to grant certain countries exemption from Australian sales tax in respect of their official purchases.

At the present time it is not possible to accurately determine the financial impact of these amendments. However, it is the Government's intention that a foreign state will be proclaimed a prescribed overseas country only where Australia is receiving a reciprocal exemption from sales or value added tax and where the cost of providing sales tax exemption in Australia is outweighed by the financial benefits of such reciprocal exemption. Therefore, the Bill is not expected to have an adverse effect on Government finances. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980, to incorporate into that Act the tariff proposal tabled in the House of Representatives on 15 September 1987. As part of the 1987-88 Budget, the proposal increased the export duty on uranium concentrate produced from the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from 15 September 1987. This export duty, which has been imposed on uranium since 1980, is to partially offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities by the Office of the Supervising Scientist associated with uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers Region. The increase in the duty proposed in this Bill will recover about 75 per cent of those costs.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist was created in recognition of the special need to protect the environment of the Alligator Rivers Region, an area of great beauty and world-wide environmental significance, from the effects of uranium mining operations both in the short and the long term. To this end, the Office of the Supervising Scientist has, amongst other things, conducted significant research on uranium tailings management, including the conduct of geomorphological studies to provide the information necessary to ensure that radioactive tailings can be contained or isolated from that environment for thousands of years. The office also monitors the effects of radiation exposure on workers involved with uranium mining, as well as on people living in the Alligator Rivers Region, and is developing strategies for the revegetation of decommissioned mine sites, so that the long-term rehabilitation of the habitat of surrounding mining areas can be planned.

The Government's continued commitment to the Office of the Supervising Scientist will ensure that the Alligator Rivers area, which includes the Kakadu National Park, is fully protected from any possible effects of uranium mining operations. Clause 4 of the Bill provides an exemption from the increased levy in the standard transitional situations where uranium concentrate was loaded on to a vessel, or was part of a consignment, the loading of which commenced prior to 15 September 1987-the commencement date of this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposed increased duty is expected to raise an additional $0.6m during that part of the 1987-88 financial year to which it applies, and an additional $0.9m in a full year. At the proposed new rate, the total uranium export levy is expected to raise $3.7m in the 1987-88 financial year and $4m in a full year. The proposed levy will now recover approximately 75 per cent of the annual cost of the uranium related monitoring and research activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the amendment that this House condemn the Government, I wish to speak on two particular points: that this House condemns the Government for placing Australian Airlines at a $4.9m per year competitive disadvantage with its major competitor, Ansett Airlines of Australia, and that this House condemns the Government for its complete failure to openly announce its intention to privatise Australian Airlines. The amount of $4.9m may not seem great; however, in a situation where Australian Airlines is already significantly hampered, it is a further competitive disadvantage to this company.

SPEECH.PARA: What constraints exist on Australian Airlines? They are many. If one examines the corporate structure of Ansett Airlines and Australian Airlines, one notes that Ansett is a company that owns airline passenger, airline freight, road passenger and road freight services; general trading, manufacturing, hotel, resort and restaurant operations, insurance interests, furniture removal and furniture storage subsidiaries, and has other associated company investments. When one compares that with Australian Airlines, one notes it has very narrow diversification: passenger service, airline freight service, Hertz Rent-a-Car and two tourist resorts.

What other constraints exist? Within the network that feeds the airlines, Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) has Air Western Australia; Air New South Wales; Skywest, New South Wales; Skywest, Western Australia; Kendall Airlines; and Lloyd Airlines; and, through its parent company, owns Bodas, which operates Aeropelican. What did Australian Airlines do? It bought Air Queensland for $9m two years ago, which went broke and closed down.

What other constraints exist? There are government constraints on Australian Airlines that inhibit its capacity to function adequately in the marketplace, constraints whereby it needs to receive Australian Loan Council approval for major equipment purchases; constraints whereby the Government has discretion to alter profit objectives; constraints whereby, being an Australian Federal organisation, it does not have access to intrastate routes; constraints whereby remuneration of board members can be influenced by tribunals; and constraints whereby broader government policies on industrial relations may hamper the airline's operations.

I give an example from the Caucus discussion paper of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), in which he said how Australian Airlines is hampered by industrial relations considerations. During lengthy industrial disputes Ansett has achieved an earlier return to work while Australian Airlines has awaited government approval for a settlement. The negotiating status of airline management is diminishing through unions' knowledge that government approval is required. Administrative arrangements reinforce the Public Service image of the airline and, most importantly, they restrict the ability of the airline management to respond directly to industrial disputes.

What further constraints already exist on Australian Airlines? The board of directors is one of the most glaring examples of the differences between the two companies. Ansett Airlines has 11 directors with an average length of service of 9.2 years. There are seven alternates who may stand for individual board members. They have an average length of service of 6.1 years. Of the alternates, five out of seven have a strong background in transport or aviation. Nine out of 11 directors have an strong background in transport or aviation. That is a very experienced and successful board. What does Australian Airlines have to compete with? It has nine government appointees for a period of five years. The average length of service is 3.8 years. Only three have any experience in business and only one has any experience in transport or aviation.

What other constraints already exist? There are constraints on efficiency. The most recent data we have on that comes from the Government's own inquiry, the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation. An appendix to that inquiry's report is the report of the firm of accountants, Travers Morgan, which was asked to study the relative efficiency of the two airlines, one a government operation and the other a private operation. That report is very telling. The company examined five measures of efficiency. In only one did Australian Airlines come out on top. In aircraft utilisation, Australian Airlines had to use its aircraft more, but perhaps only because it was strapped for cash. In unit cost-that is, cost per passenger kilometre-Australian Airlines cost 10.5 per cent more than Ansett for any given length of flight. In passenger revenue yield-that is, the revenue per passenger kilometre-Australian Airlines was 15 per cent down on Ansett. It got 15 per cent less revenue per kilometre. In labour productivity, Australian Airlines was 8 per cent down. In profitability-that is, the return on assets-Ansett's was 9 per cent and Australian Airlines was 5.1 per cent-76 per cent down.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to address some of the comments that some of the previous speakers have made. The honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) made five points, to which I which to allude. He said, firstly, it was strange that the Opposition was not letting Australian Airlines pay its way in its superannuation liabilities. It is really very simple. It is not a matter of not letting it pay its way; it is a matter of not allowing another competitive disadvantage to affect an airline that is already struggling to compete. It is not $4.9m once-off; it is this amount of money for every year to come.

Secondly, the honourable member seemed to think incorporation would solve the problems. Yet, according the Minister's own documents, incorporation will still not remove the controls or solve the capital requirements of the airline.

Thirdly, the honourable member for Aston said there was nothing logical to suggest that a public company is less efficient than a private company. I suggest he read something other than his Labor Party briefing notes. David Davies from the Duke University, Peter Forsyth from the University of New South Wales, Richard Hocking from the University of Melbourne, Michael Kirby and Robert Albon from the Australian National University, have written extensively on this subject for the last 18 years in the Economic Record and United States Journal of Law and Economics.

Everyone studying Australia's two airlines has come to exactly the same conclusion: other things being equal-which they are in the case of the two airlines, running the same routes with the same fares-a private company is more efficient than a public company. This is backed up by the May report.

The fourth point raised by the honourable member for Aston was a criticism of the previous Government for not injecting capital into Australian Airlines. He looks at the issue very superficially. The originally capital injection of $15m in 1961 was considered adequate at the time. Subsequent to that, Australian Airlines met its requirements through borrowings. It had no trouble with Loan Council requirements. It was only in the very late 1970s that this became a disadvantage and an inquiry was set up by the Fraser Government to look at the capital requirements of Australian Airlines. When that reported in 1982 a further $25m was injected as an interim measure. This is quite important. The report of the Department of Aviation for the year 1983 says very clearly that in December 1982 the then Government approved an interim increase in Trans Australian Airlines capital of $25m. The honourable member for Aston seems to be heartily congratulating his Government on injecting a further $90m eight weeks after it went into government. All that was said in his own Party's policy at that time was that it would review airline capital requirements. If he really suggests that anything more than the Minister's name on the letterhead was changed and that the full results of that inquiry were carried through eight weeks before the decision was made, he is kidding himself. If capital injection was such a vitally important issue, why did Australian Airlines itself not make any reference to it in its submission to the May committee?

It was the May committee, not Australian Airlines, that brought up the issue of capital injection. The history of capital injection into Australian Airlines was very proper until the late 1970s, when the circumstances changed and the appropriate measures were taken. Criticism of the previous Government is quite irrelevant. I note that nothing was done in the period of the Whitlam Government.

The honourable member for Aston in his fifth point cited page 62 of the May report as supporting his argument as to why Australian Airlines should remain under Government control. I have with me one volume of the May report. It is a 1,000 page document. The honourable member for Aston has picked out three lines, made in passing, in a paragraph of a chapter dealing with policy options. This paragraph is couched in such terms as `it may', `assume', and `be more reasonable' and follows a statement that `it is unlikely that Australian would force Ansett out of the market'. If the honourable member looks again at his Minister's own Caucus document he will see that his own Minister has stated that `public ownership provides an absolute guarantee against the emergence of a private monopoly; however, the same outcome can be assured by making Australian a viable competitor and subjecting the industry to the application of the Trade Practices Act'. If all the honourable member for Aston can do to support his argument is to take three lines in this document out of context, he has a very weak argument.

The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) made several points. He talked at length of the history of the airline agreement. I found it very interesting to learn what was happening here when my father was finishing high school, but I am afraid that I do not see the point. All the legislation that he talked about, in his own words, to remove competitive advantage, is not as he painted it. It is quite reasonable in an industry which has barriers to entry for government to ensure that new competitors can enter that field. Because of the enormous capital requirements of any entry into the airline industry, again it is a reasonable role for government to ensure that barriers to entry do not stop other players. Secondly, a government-owned organisation may very well have unfair competitive advantages. It is a reasonable role for government to ensure that those unfair competitive advantages do not stifle new industry. It was a very appropriate policy 35 years ago; it is not an appropriate policy now. The policies of the Opposition, when implemented in government, will free up the airline industry so that that competition is appropriate for the 1990s.

The honourable member for Chifley was very good in looking back 35 years. I prefer to look to the future, not to the past. If Australian Airlines is not to remain a second rate irrelevancy, it will need to be privatised, allowed access to cash, and allowed access to the competition that a private firm would give it.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1987[COGNATE BILL:INCOME TAX (OFFSHORE BANKING UNITS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 December 1987, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 concurrently with the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) contains a substantial number of amendments to the existing taxation laws. It is another of the Government's large omnibus Bills of around 50 pages and clauses. Many of those 50 clauses deal with what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) euphemistically calls `unintended consequences' arising from his previous tax changes. The other shorter Bill, the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, which we are dealing with cognately, provides for the imposition of a penalty where alterations to the laws affecting withholding tax paid by offshore banking units are abused.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not be opposing either Bill. However, we will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) to highlight the general taxpayer's total dissatisfaction with the heavy burden of the Government's taxation policies. Accordingly, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:
(a) this Government is the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia;
(b) an estimated 24.5 per cent of GDP in 1987-88 will be collected in tax revenue;
(c) there will be an estimated $71 billion in taxation revenue in 1987-88, a $5.5 billion increase on the previous year's collection;
(d) the Government has increasingly burdened not only individuals but business with new incentive-sapping taxes like the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax; and

(e) without the incentive to invest and work productively, Australia will find it increasingly difficult to extricate itself from its $83 billion foreign debt strait jacket without further reductions in our standard of living'.

I said in the amendment that I have just moved that this Government is the highest taxing government in post-war history. An estimated 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product will be collected in Commonwealth taxation revenue in the financial year 1987-88.

This Government unquestionably thrives on revenue collection. Little attention has been given to cutting back its wasteful expenditures because it has no compunction in squeezing more income out of the long-suffering taxpayer. The reaction to this was seen in the Adelaide by-election when a meandering Prime Minister, muttering about not a question of principle but imposing further taxes and charges on an electorate, could not comprehend, because he is the leader of a government that has lost touch with the Australian people, that they have been squeezed and squeezed dry.

The Budget Papers estimate that total revenue collection in 1987-88 will increase by a massive $5.9 billion. That is an increase from an already very high level. Total collections of $72.2 billion were made in 1986-87. Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been talking of announcing cuts in both business and personal tax rates at the time of the mini-Budget which is to be brought down in May. But we on this side of the House warn the people about expecting too much. After all, the New South Wales election will be before the May statement, the mini-Budget, and once it is out of the way that incentive will disappear. It appears from the polls that the Prime Minister's cynical grab for votes will not succeed.

The Prime Minister has given no indication of rates, nor any indication as to when a cut in the rates will actually be delivered. In fact, the Treasurer's office is putting it out that nothing is planned definitely in any case. So it is the old smokescreen again to try to tidy up New South Wales. But, as we have seen in the desperate endeavours by the Premier, that is a lost cause. What are they going to tell us in the days ahead? Will it be next financial year, as the Prime Minister's statements have tended to imply, or the financial year after that, as the spokesman for the Treasurer has implied? For how long will the Government rake in the windfall increase in revenues from bracket creep before deigning to give taxpayers relief? The Government has used bracket creep to finance its huge expenditures. Such cuts would not be real reductions but simply stopping tax rises from which the Government will otherwise automatically benefit. A reduction in the tax burden requires cuts in wasteful Government expenditure.

In short, the Prime Minister's discussion on tax cuts is, as I say, a cynical political exercise which he cannot hope to deliver. But he has raised the expectations of Australians who clamour for relief from Labor's high taxation burden. These expectations will just not be fulfilled and the Government, then, will receive the condemnation it justly deserves from an electorate wrung dry as the lemon is squeezed more and more. There is little evidence that the Government is in fact prepared to cut expenditure to finance meaningful tax cuts for low and middle income earners.

Let me turn to a more specific area of taxation, namely, business taxation. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 implements proposals to exempt from interest withholding tax interest paid to non-residents by offshore banking units that operate in Australia. This interest withholding tax exemption is basically intended to encourage offshore transactions, in particular on-lending to non-residents. The Opposition welcomes these proposals which in effect represent a further encouraging step along the road of financial deregulation. However, put in context, they do not go far enough in that one of the real disadvantages in attracting off-shore banking on investment generally is our comparatively high corporate tax rates. Of course, this topic has come to the fore over the last two weeks following the announcement across the Tasman of New Zealand's proposed tax reforms. Those recent announcements highlight yet again Australia's comparative lack of international competitiveness. Australia's corporate tax rate structure is just out of step with many of our competitors in the world marketplace. If the Prime Minister and the Treasurer do not realise this, they simply are shutting their eyes to reality. Indeed, given their single-minded approach to grasping more revenue, it is more a case of turning an already blind eye to the reality.

Last year the Government raised company tax from 46c in the dollar to 49c. At a time when the Government was talking tax relief, the corporate rate actually rose to 49 per cent. That compares unfavourably with the top effective rates in Pacific Basin countries of 39 per cent in the United States of America, 28 per cent in Canada, 45 per cent in Japan, 48 per cent in Malaysia, 33 per cent in Singapore, 25 per cent in Taiwan, 18 per cent in Hong Kong, 43.7 per cent in South Korea and, now, 28 per cent in New Zealand. These figures may seem slightly different from those which are usually quoted. For example, we often hear that the United States company tax rate is 34 per cent. However, the figures that I have just given include all levels of government. Therefore, in the United States, there is beside the Federal tax an estimated 5 per cent effective States' tax. This data, taking into account all of the accumulated taxes, is even more relevant in a comparison of countries. That data shows that Australia has the highest rate of all of the significant trade competitors that I have mentioned.

Many commentators have argued that just examining top marginal rates is too narrow and that other taxation concessions should be taken into account. However, on that point a study commissioned by the Business Council of Australia has revealed that Australia's depreciation rates, particularly when depreciation on buildings is taken into account, are not significantly more generous than those of other nations. In addition, the Government has increasingly introduced incentive sapping taxes such as its capital gains tax.

Honourable members will note that tax Bill (No. 5) also contains changes to the capital gains tax provisions. Roll-over relief will be given where a resident company is interposed between a unit trust and its unit holders who dispose of their units to the company in exchange solely for non-redeemable shares in the company. This amendment is just one more in a long list of changes to the capital gains tax legislation since its introduction in 1986.

During the debate late last year on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, I noted the sorry state of this taxation legislation and what a complicated burden the Government has placed on taxpayers. Because of the capital gains tax, uncertainties, unintended consequences and, therefore, injustices abound. It was plain that further roll-over relief for business was needed. I said then, when speaking on taxation Bill (No. 3), that we would obviously be seeing more legislation-and here it is-in this House in the coming years. Unfortunately, that prediction does not change even today as this Government stumbles on in this bewildering arena, altering its hastily prepared and ill-considered legislation.

Of course, taxes are not the only factor influencing the location of investment. The Government has yet to reveal the results of its deals with the Australian Council of Trade Unions over wage-tax cuts trade-offs. What the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have continually failed to mention is that wages policy is a major reason why Australia remains a relatively unattractive place for foreign investment, as evidenced by our low level of investment in plant and equipment. Indeed, the figures that came out yesterday showed a further significant decline in investment in plant and equipment in this country. So the engine for growth is just slowing down.

The Government has consistently supported across the board increases in nominal wages without productivity offsets. Wage increases without productivity offsets simply lead to inflation, leaving nobody better off. Australia cannot afford inflation indexed wage rises in addition to tax cuts, as suggested by the Prime Minister during the weekend. There seems to be a whole web of confusion on this issue in the Government. I note that, on the Sunday program last weekend, when the Prime Minister discussed wages he did not even mention productivity. The Prime Minister talks blandly about raising people's standards of living. The major reason our standard of living has not improved much in recent years is the abysmal productivity performance in Australia. It is simple: Labor's economic policies have failed to raise productivity.

Let me now turn to another important business taxation area which is dealt with in tax Bill (No. 5). The legislation seeks to remedy some minor shortcomings in the existing taxation laws with respect to lump sum superannuation and kindred payments. While these amendments appear acceptable, the Government should realise that they have been causing enormous-and that is not too strong a word-distress in the community over the general issue of superannuation. I do not say in relation to these specific measures but in respect of other measures that have been the subject of some discussion in the House today. My office and the offices of all other Opposition members have been deluged with calls from people, many of whom, quite frankly, are distraught over the possible changes to the taxation of superannuation and their ability to receive lump sum payments. We have heard that over a dozen-is it 17?-senior pilots from Qantas Airways Ltd have recently retired for this very reason. We have also heard stories about similar large retirements sweeping through firms and organisations. The stories can be substantiated.

Only last week we were notified that large numbers of people had left or were close to leaving the Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria-all over the fear arising from the rumours about superannuation. This fear did not result from the changes in this legislation, but a number of amendments in it may have touched off the rumours in the broader field. It is the role of government to allay those fears, not to create them. This Government must explain what it is doing and ensure that it does not impose changes with a retrospective effect-and I will come back to that in a moment-on people's financial positions. This Government has created fear in people's minds.

The Treasury has been working on a paper that provides for taxing the superannuation funds and their profits. God knows what Treasury officials have been working on in relation to lump sum payments. Nobody knows. It is as if the Government is treating this whole matter with contempt. People plan their whole life span with a nest egg at the end of it. Successive generations in this nation have been encouraged to put something aside for their retirement. That could be jeopardised and not explained. There is an underlying fear and in that case it is understandable.

Of course, this has created a very different form of fear in the mind of the plodding Premier of New South Wales-that is, the fear of losing. He has just lumbered-or stumbled-into the arena and called on the Federal Government to come clean and get its hands out of people's superannuation. Just as the reality of defeat is dawning on him, he feels that he had better alert the attention of the Federal Government to the plight of people. He too recognises the charge that the community is making on this Government, that it has lost touch with ordinary Australians. Poor old Barrie! I have never seen a fellow who more consistently looks like the man who has just missed the last train. No doubt a major contributing factor is this particular concern at the moment. It is fear, but a differently motivated fear from that which the community has at present. For the life of me I do not understand why this Government has created this fear in the community and why it will not come clean. We did not get much out of the Prime Minister today, other than the reality that this Government is looking at the matter.

Honourable members will not hear from the Treasurer on this matter because he has a vastly different sort of fear. He fears that, if he makes the running on this matter, he may not get up as the successor, the anointed one. There is not much doubt on this side of the House that the current Prime Minister will be gone by December. I take no notice of all the backgroundings from his office that the Prime Minister's retirement is certainly not on. He does not want to be regarded as the so-called lame duck. The Prime Minister will deny this, but he is cutting and running. The end of this Government is in sight. The Prime Minister is going before the end and the anointed one will take over. One never hears from the Treasurer on an issue such as this. Where was he on the ID card-this essential element of economic policy? Where was he in the ID card debate, on the matter of collecting the tax due? Cut it out, mate! He fled from that as fast as he could. Where was he in the Adelaide by-election? He dropped in one morning, dumped the time charges issue on the Prime Minister-the so-called economically rational approach-and skedaddled to Europe. Where is he on this issue? Oh, no! With all the signs of erosion in front of the Government of opposition to the transition and with all the mutterings about the capacity of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is now the Vice-President of the Executive Council and Leader of the House-God knows where he is leading us after the last two days of confusion in this House-we have the image of the macho Treasurer who takes the tough decisions running from every tough political issue in the course of the last six months. That is why he will not come clean.

People out there are confused and they are entitled to know what this Government is doing. Should the Government go ahead, that decision will not affect the Government's superannuation; it will affect individual people and their futures. I am sure that it will not be introduced before the current Prime Minister flees. It may well be that poor blundering Barrie is making these noises not so much out of fear for the electorate, but out of fear that, having won his seat by only 54 votes, he is a rolled-gold, lay-down misere to lose it in a few weeks time. He wants to shore up his own, either way. The motivation for the confusion and concern is the fear of a great many people in the electorate. What this Government is doing to them is cruel and unnecessary and, unless it comes clean on the matter, I predict that the fears will be exacerbated in the minds of so many who are already considering leaving their places of employment.

Furthermore, the Government is adopting a blinkered approach to corporate tax reform. It is talking of a revenue neutral outcome. This means that, instead of making the expenditure cuts to allow a reduction in the tax burden, it will simply shift that burden around. In the process, it is understood that it is seeking company tax reductions as an offset to increase tax in the area of superannuation. I do not know precisely what the Government intends, nor does the Premier of New South Wales, but this could be the wrong policy focus.

I mentioned the matter of retrospectivity in this arena, for there is a whiff of retrospectivity in the air. People have been organising their financial affairs, based, I assume, on existing arrangements. To change these rules with any retrospective or retroactive effect would be similar to breaking an implicit contract with the taxpayer. The Government should now reduce the increasing uncertainty in the community by giving an indication of its intentions, especially as to whether people will be allowed to receive lump sum payments and whether any retrospectivity is proposed.

Lastly, I note that there is strong doubt that the provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) relating to the exclusion of what are called `variable annuities' from the category of annuities eligible for taxation concessions are exactly the same as those announced in the Treasurer's Press release of 12 January 1987. Mr Deputy Speaker, it would not be inappropriate to draw your attention, as a member of this House, to this matter. Although you are sitting in an unbiased way at present, I know of the pungent attacks that you have made, when you are not in such an objective frame of mind as you are now, on legislation by Press release. I urge you to examine this carefully and, should you agree with what I say, on leaving the chair to join me in bringing this particular point to the attention of the people of Australia. If it is the case that the legislation differs from what is contained in the Press release of 12 January 1987-a fair time ago-a fair number of people would have been operating precisely in terms of that Press release. If the legislation is different I would welcome the view of whichever Minister is here-and they seem to rotate from time to time-at the end of this debate. Given that the legislation's operation is backdated to the Press release, there is again a strong element of retrospectivity. I have no problem with legislation operating from the date of a Press release, but I expect that legislation to be brought in speedily after the announcement and for it to mirror accurately-no more-what the Press release states. On this element of retrospectivity, this is especially the case for those taxpayers who have been operating on the basis of the Press release that was issued by the Government. This would then simply be another case of the Government causing unnecessary distress by delayed legislative action after the issue of that Press release.

In summary, let us hope that the Government presents substantive changes to taxation this year but, as we proposed, financed by cutting wasteful expenditure in the Budget. When we talk about tax cuts, we relate them to cuts in government expenditure. We say that one depends on the other. This Government should not rely simply on the increases in revenue inflow resulting from bracket creep as inflation bites at low to middle income families. The Government should embark on genuine tax reform financed by cuts in expenditure rather than meaningless revenue neutral exercises which do not address the fundamental problem of the tax policy-and that is Labor's `big government' fixation. This is the only way to reduce the burden on individuals and businesses. It is the only way to create the incentive to work and to invest to pave the way for the release of resources so that we can trade our way out of the $83 billion foreign debt straitjacket without a continual decline in our standard of living.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to take part in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. These are the latest in a group of Bills which reflect the Government's commitment to attack, through legislation rather than through Press release, which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) referred to earlier, the subject of tax reform. For a number of years this Government has been committed to ensuring that taxpayers pay their fair share, and that all income earners contribute to the provision of services which this Government and other levels of government in this country must equally contribute. I have no compunction whatever in suggesting that a number of points made in the opening remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer were made purely with political intentions in mind. The fact that the New South Wales election is coming up may have had something to do with it. I suspect that some of the honourable member's comments went straight to the heart of that issue. I will be pleased to respond to some of those matters later in my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will amend various taxation laws to a range of policy decisions of the Government. That issue is most important. There is a vast difference between Labor members and Opposition members, because Labor has policies. I have been in this place for just over three years and have spoken quite often in this place on the subject of taxation and the policy issues associated with taxation and finance. I continually come back to the same position and find myself asking the same basic questions: Where are the Opposition policies that can be shown to the people of Australia which can stand scrutiny and pass the most important test of all, the test of the ballot box? I have not yet seen those policies, and will return to that issue in a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a long time off, too.

—As my colleague the Minister suggests, it will be a long time off. The measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) are many and various. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that changes were continually being occasioned by the Government's reform packages and the policies that were coming forward. He saw that as a bad position to adopt. I would ask the honourable member to check with his Opposition colleagues who formerly occupied the Treasurer's role whether there have been previous examples of government finding it necessary to amend taxation laws. Because of changed circumstances, because of arguments advanced by people in the community, have there been no earlier examples when taxation laws were found to be in need of alteration? If one looks at the volume of taxation legislation, one can see the changes which have occurred over a period of time. The answer to my questions obviously must be in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the developments set out in the two Bills that are now before the House, I would point out that the proposals will give effect to the Government's decision announced on 1 July 1986, and expanded on 9 April 1987, to provide an interest withholding tax exemption to facilitate offshore banking in Australia, primarily for dealings in foreign currency for non-residents. Effect is also being given to the proposal announced on 29 September 1987 to extend roll-over relief-that is, deferral of liability-from tax on capital gains for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts. The Bill implements two additional changes announced in November last year to the concessions for expenditure on scientific research and other qualifying research and development activities. Clearly, this will ensure a more efficient use of revenue available for research and development activities by simply focusing on more productive and innovative investment.

I am sure that honourable members will have heard-indeed, they have probably read about them-the Government's commitment to ensuring that more productive and innovative investments are focused on research and development initiatives. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) is constantly preaching this need in Australia. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has also become a fervent supporter of the need for innovative changes in Australian industry to make it more productive and competitive. The Government recognises that. Indeed, some of these measures are aimed at facilitating that process. Honourable members who have had the chance to travel overseas in the Pacific Rim area and further afield will have visited some of the countries with which we are directly competing. I am sure many members have taken the opportunity to look at what Japanese industry has to offer and the lessons to be learned there. We also have seen the lessons that can be learned from what is happening in the Republic of China and Taiwan. Again, we can learn from that experience. It is now incumbent on industry to take up those measures which the Government, through its taxation policies, has put in place to enable that process to take place.

The Bill also ensures that measures are included which are complementary to those introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) to permit a newly incorporated company-commonly referred to as a shelf company-to be eligible for various company grouping provisions of the income tax law. All those measures tidy up somewhat matters that were identified in the broad community when this legislation was proposed and in existing tax laws and are a direct reaction to the Government's responsibility to make changes as the need arises.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition spoke of reacting to changes in taxation laws, as I mentioned earlier. He spoke of unintended consequences which perhaps the Government did not foresee when drawing up the variety of legislation on tax reform. I do not accept that that is the case. This legislation is a reaction to the fact that the Government, through successive taxation amendments, is seeking to ensure that people pay their fair share, that there is equity in the tax system, and that people and companies which previously did not pay their fair share and which perhaps indulged in tax evasion and avoidance but have now been found out are now contributing to this country.

As I have said previously in debates on taxation, we have to go a little beyond speculating about why governments collect taxes. We have to look to the reasons why that is necessary. As I have indicated, it is because this Government-in fact, any government at the Federal, State or local level-is responsible for providing a variety of services to the people of this country. Money, much as we would like to see it, does not grow on the proverbial tree. People have to contribute to their upkeep and contribute fairly and equally to ensure that that burden of responsibility is borne right across the spectrum. The Government is of the view that through its various taxation reform measures in the business and personal income tax areas, that aim is being achieved.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talked about the heavy burden of the Government's taxation policies. Is reducing the top marginal rate from 60c to 49c a heavy burden? Are all the other consequential changes that collapsed those tax scales downwards a burden on the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer? I suspect not. If we look back five years, before the Australian Labor Party came to government, we see what was in place then. We have heard the empty rhetoric about changes that were on the way, but they were not in place. When the Liberal and National parties went out of government they left behind a 60c in the dollar top marginal tax rate and a series of other business imposts which they did not have the political will to tackle, yet they purport to represent those people in the community. Now they sit back and wonder why that support has deserted them in droves. I certainly know why that is the case. They complain about the Government's imposition of the fringe benefits tax (FBT) and the capital gains tax, saying that they are incentive-sapping taxes, to use the words of the honourable member for Kooyong. The people in the low and middle income brackets are not too concerned about the FBT and the capital gains tax. I remember when those taxes were being brought in the scare campaign that was being run by honourable members opposite about who the taxes were going to affect. I remember this being one of the tough political issues referred to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not run away from. The Deputy Leader went to great pains to say that the Treasurer runs away from every tough political issue. Let me tell the House that I will put my money on the Treasurer against the Deputy Leader of the Opposition any time when it comes to financial and economic matters and taxation issues.

In the last five years we have seen that the Treasurer of this country has had the political will, the guts and the integrity to take forward the changes necessary in taxation. This is reflected in the Bills with which we are dealing this afternoon and in other taxation measures that have been put in place. He has been prepared to shape policy, to drag this country forward, to give it a competitive edge so that people in the business community can have some advantage to compete on the world scene. He has been able to drag down those marginal tax rates so that those at the lower end of the scale, as well as the middle income earners, have been able to get some relief from the taxation burdens that have been imposed, not by us but by those on the other side of the House before they went out of government.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also made some comments about corporate tax rates. Let me talk also about the question of retrospectivity. The honourable member for Kooyong referred to that matter in his treatment of superannuation. I put to him that we had to be a bit careful about this. One never knows, the Qantas pilot out there at The Oaks might change his vote one day and it might be important to us. More importantly, we have to consider these people and the question of retrospectivity. That brings into question the basic issue of why superannuation was put in place. This Government has deliberately pursued a policy of trying to get superannuation in place because of its recognition that Australia's population is ageing. As the population ages, so too does the requirement on government-any government that is in power at the Federal level-to provide social security benefits of varying degrees for those aging members of our society. If through the working life of those people we can get them to contribute to superannuation and if they know that at the end of that working life there is something that will see them through after the age of 65, it is our duty and our right to look at that in a fair and reasonable way.

The Government has already indicated in regard to superannuation, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to this in Question Time today, that there are aspects that are being examined as part of our total review of the corporate tax structure and the taxation structure generally. I conclude by saying that I totally agreed with the Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, when he stated recently that the Liberal and National parties did not deserve to win the election in July because they simply were not ready. The people of Australia would also like to know what the Opposition has to offer, rather than the empty rhetoric that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition comes in here with. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), earlier in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill which are before the chamber. SPEECH.PARA: The proposal in the Bills to exempt from interest withholding tax interest paid to non-residents by offshore banking units that operate in Australia is a further encouraging sign pointing towards financial deregulation.
