For instance, Australia's overseas borrowings currently stand at a staggering $115 billion and are growing at an incredible $200m a week. This debt is equal to a crushing $16,000 for every taxpayer. The interest payments paid on borrowings, of course, lead to higher taxes, charges and prices, which means that each income earner must in effect now find approximately $25 a week to meet interest payments.

Although Australia's highest marginal rate has been reduced to 49 per cent or, more accurately 50.25 per cent when the Medicare levy is included, the high rate cuts in on salary levels far below those of other countries and it is the modest middle income earner in Australia who is hardest hit. If an Australian receives $1 of income more than $35,000 he or she moves into the top tax rate of 49c in the dollar. Yet if one compares that with the situation in a number of other countries, one finds that it is a very unflattering comparison. No Englishman would pay 49c in the dollar until he earned $A60,000 or more. No Japanese would pay 49c in the dollar until he earned $A200,000 or more and no American would ever pay 49c in the dollar. So much for the concern being expressed from the other side of the House about the middle income earner!

Compounding the taxation burden now faced by Australian families is the fact that there is little relief available to them through tax exempt deductions. Furthermore, rebates for dependants are laughable when compared with those in many other countries. This Government seems to forget that Australia's future lies in its children. It is little wonder that our birth rate has been so depressingly low in recent times.

Australians have few legal means of limiting their tax. The most significant item, of course, is the deductibility of contributions to certain superannuation funds to a limit of $1,500 for wage and salary earners. However, when one takes an overseas comparison, that limit is shown to be quite minuscule. In Canada, the deductible maximum for an employee is $A8,060; in the United States of America it is $A2,800, and in Sweden it is $A11,095. In Australia, a married man is entitled to a maximum tax rebate for a wife and child, or children, of $1,030, reducing by $1 of every $4 by which the income of the dependants exceeds $280 a year. Therefore, if a wife earns as little as $75 a week the rebate disappears. It should be pointed out that, generally, personal allowances in most other countries far exceed those in Australia. In Canada, the single taxpayer can claim a basic personal allowance of $A4,537, indexed for inflation, and a further $A3,978 is available as a spouse allowance. This allowance does not reduce until the spouse's income exceeds $A600.

I think that the most interesting thing to note is that, under this Government, the big business friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have increased their personal wealth to unimaginable levels while the average Australian family, which this Government makes so much of, has suffered under even more onerous taxation and pseudo-taxation impositions. The cost in 1987 of supporting a five-year-old child was estimated to be $37.63 a week, or $1,956.76 a year. The cost of supporting a teenager was $92.16 a week, or $4,792.32 a year. I shall now turn to the separate but related issue of superannuation, which is also addressed by the legislation before us tonight. These Bills are introducing some changes to superannuation. There is no doubt that superannuation is a matter of great importance to Australians, who are increasingly taking advantage of superannuation policies in an effort to ensure that they are able to enjoy a comfortable lifestyle in their retirement, a lifestyle denied to them during their working lives under the favoured mates taxation policies of this Government's New South Wales-based right wing and particularly of the Prime Minister.

This Government has succeeded in frightening everyone to death through its mishandling of the superannuation issue. As evidence of this, I can tell the House that my own electorate office has been absolutely inundated by constituents worried about what the Government may be considering for superannuation. Some are so frightened by what the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) may do, to deprive them of their rights to decide for themselves how best to use their invested superannuation, that they are seriously considering early retirement in an attempt to prevent the Prime Minister and the Treasurer taking away something for which they have struggled long and hard.

This brings me to my next point. If the Government has any understanding at all of the electorate's mood, it should move now, rather than wait for the May economic statement, to allay the fears of the electorate on the issue of superannuation. We do not need any more procrastination such as we saw during Question Time today by the Prime Minister. I remain pessimistic that the Government will do this. With the Prime Minister and the Treasurer now spending so much of their time rubbing shoulders with Australia's super-rich, they have come to regard the majority of Australians, that is, those struggling to make ends meet, as inconsequential. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer no longer have any idea of what issues are of concern to middle Australia.

My colleague the shadow Treasurer and I believe that any changes to superannuation should be made in the context of a complete retirement income policy package and not part of a blanket overhaul to offset changes to company taxation. I am against any proposal at all to further restrict the rights of Australians reaching retirement to do as they see fit with their superannuation. I am opposed to any changes that would further limit the amount that a person retiring from the work force could take as a lump sum payment.

It would appear from the Press this morning that battling Barrie Unsworth, the beleaguered Premier of New South Wales, shares that view. For instance, this morning's edition of the Melbourne Age reported what he had to say:
Mr Unsworth said that `one of the things I want to put an end to is the suggestion that there might be a tax on superannuation funds'.
He is further quoted in the Canberra Times:
Mr Unsworth admitted that Labor's traditional supporters were disillusioned that their wages had declined in real value in recent years while wealthier sections of the community had prospered.
I guess that is what the result in Adelaide was very largely all about. Finally, Mr Unsworth sums it up, I guess very succinctly, in today's Australian Financial Review:

Mr Unsworth said he opposed the taxation of superannuation funds and suggestions of curtailing lump sum payments because both proposals would disadvantage people who had saved for many years to finance their retirement. `They're matters I want to put to rest,' he said.
I am sure that he does want to put them to rest before the electors of New South Wales put him to rest for all time.

In overall terms, the Opposition does not oppose the Bills now before the House, but it expresses great reservation about the current state of the Government's corporate and personal tax regimes and, in particular, the terrible financial position in which they have placed the average family in middle Australia.

I hope that one day I will be able to say in here that all the problems are over. That really is a magic wand land. Regardless of the changes the Government makes, there will be those anomalies. Too often concerns have been created by the people I mentioned before, like the employers and the David Barnetts. If I had one wish I would like one day to pick up my own Morning Bulletin in central Queensland to read the David Barnett column and find one comment that he makes that is positive and supportive of the Hawke Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hard to find.

—We never hear him say it. I think that he must get up in the morning and suck lemons before he begins writing his column. I should like to think that one day I will see that. I should also like to hear some employers start telling the truth when they are explaining what the Government intends to do. I suggest that the Hawke Government has earned an excellent and well-deserved reputation as a tax reforming government, perhaps the tax reforming government of the twentieth century. SPEECH.PARA: There will always be problems, and I want to mention one problem that I believe needs to be addressed, that is, the loophole that seems to exist in the prescribed payments tax. I have talked with the Building Workers Industrial Union, the Builders Labourers Federation, the plumbers union and the painters union. I note the Deputy Speaker smiling when I mention them, but they have a special interest in their membership and, in this instance, they are taking a very strong national interest in the issues they are raising. They have pointed out that we are plagued at the moment with pseudo-contractors in the construction industry. There are 103,000 people in the construction industry and it has been suggested that the minimum bottom line would be that one in 10 of these are not PAYE employees but are playing the game of the subcontractor and are doing it in a false way. In doing so, they are paying, in most instances, only 15 per cent tax under the current prescribed payments tax system. Their employers are happy with it because there are some advantages to them, too, and I will explain that in a moment.

There are so many of these fellows, and if the figure is one in 10, that means we are talking about 10,000 just in the construction industry. There are another 50,000 people in the motor vehicle industry and there are some five industries tied under the prescribed payments system. Therefore, we are talking about a lot of people. I have spoken to the Australian Taxation Office about it, and it has said, `Our hands are tied. We are virtually handcuffed because we have not had the human resources. Our inspectors have not been able to get out there and follow it up'. The employers encourage workers to register as subcontractors under the prescribed payments system. The advantage to an employer is that he pays no holiday pay or loading, no workers compensation, no payroll tax and no overtime payments. He is also in a very good position to lower his tender price when fighting for contracts. However, it is a very costly practice for Australians.

From the subcontractors' point of view, there are also some advantages, because these pseudo-subcontractors are paid slightly above the award; they are often paid in cash; and they have to pay, in most instances, only 15 per cent tax up front and sometimes that is all the tax they pay. Sometimes, I am told, they use bodgie tax file numbers. As the House is aware, under the law, no employer can ring up the Taxation Office and check a tax file number. He has to take what the employee says to be true. These subcontractors pay no more tax, because they tend to move around the industry. As the tax fellows have said to me, at least they are getting 15 per cent from these people. Under the Liberals and Nationals, before 1983 when this Government introduced the prescribed payments tax system, the Taxation Office was getting nothing. At least it is now getting 15 per cent.

Obviously this is wrong, and it is a costly practice because, in 1986-87, the total amount of money derived in tax revenue from the prescribed payments system was $765m. That is a massive amount of money when one considers that that is 15 per cent of the gross earnings of people within five industries. It is estimated that next year it could be as much as $900m. I put it to honourable members that if one in 10 are involved in this rort we are talking about a loss in the coming year of some $90m. But it is as some of the union leaders have told me-that it could be 20 per cent, 25 per cent or one in three-we could be talking about a $200m loss in the coming financial year. When one adds to this the black cash practices in the domestic market where the prescribed payments tax applies on jobs over $10,000, the problem just boggles the mind.

It is a common practice for builders and painters who are going around painting houses, extending rooms and so on to say to people, `Look, it is $3,000, but pay me cash and I'll drop it to $2,500'. It is a major problem that tax cannot be collected. There are some solutions to the current problems, the first of which is that we must change the definition of `subcontractor' within the Income Tax Assessment Act. We also have to tidy up the master-servant relationship that tax officers have to work upon. We must ensure that only those who are true subcontractors are involved in the prescribed payments tax system, and we must also lower the threshold on domestic contracts from $10,000.

It may sound revolutionary, but I suggest that the tax form ought to be changed in some way so that people can be asked to list the payments that they have made to builders and to painters in the last financial year. They would not be required to pay any tax on it, but the contractor and the painter would know that there was a chance of cross-checking, that if the customer they dealt with during the year lists their name and how much he spent, there is a chance that the taxation people could follow it up. If that occurred, I believe we could stop that black cash transaction racket overnight.

From the subcontractors' point of view, however, we must consider the problems in the Taxation Office and give more human resources, revamp the definition of subcontractor to make it tougher, and develop some link or parallel between the PAYE system whereby the employer collects tax on behalf of other employees and the prescribed payments system. As the law says, if the subcontractor does not supply a tax file number, he does not have 15 per cent taken from his earnings or the invoice statement of labour content; he has 30 per cent taken.

I suggest that if we were to introduce a prescribed payment tax rate of at least 25 per cent and let the employer take that out, our problem would be resolved. We could be saving ourselves $100m, $150m or even $200m a year. Action is being taken, and this coming Friday I will meet in Brisbane with leaders of the four major unions, and a union dossier will be given to the Taxation Office naming businesses and those who we believe are the pseudo-subcontractors.

I mentioned also the problem of pensioners paying provisional tax. I raised this issue in the House two years ago. I appreciate that the review is under way and that reviews take time, but the present exemption threshold is only $1,000 and any person or pensioner who earns in excess of $1,000 in addition to his or her income, salary or wages-and that includes pensions-from interest or dividends or any other investment must pay provisional tax.

The threshold of $1,000 has been there for almost 10 years. In 1979 it was $400 and was raised in the Budget at the time by the previous Government to $1,000. I am told that the cost of increasing the threshold from $400 to $1,000 was $15m. It may not seem important to many people who they say that it is only a one-off payment by the pensioners because the next year they will get that payment back if they do not earn more than $1,000. But we appreciate the fact that today it is not a lot to have $12,000 in the bank earning 10 per cent interest and to be over the $1,000 threshold.

In 1984-85, 240,000 pensioners were affected by provisional tax in this nation. In 1985-86 the figure rose to 260,000, and I am told by tax authorities that in this coming financial year the figure will jump to a massive 340,000 to 350,000 pensioners paying provisional tax. I just do not believe that is how it ought to be. It means that something like 350,000 of the two million aged pensioners and veterans face provisional tax bills this year; 350,000 people with a limited ability to pay; people who have their money in fixed term investments and who are going to dislocate and dislodge that investment in order to pick up the $500 or $900 they are now called upon to pay in provisional tax.

Every credit should be given to this Government for what it has done in raising pensions and introducing tax rebates for those people who earn up to $1,000. But we cannot leave it at that. It was excellent when people were earning $20 a week over and above their pensions and they knew there was a total tax rebate of $250 to cover that. However, that is no longer the case, because people can earn $40 a week and find that they have to pay tax on that. The pensioners will wear that in most cases but they will not accept provisional tax. They will not accept the fact that they are paying double tax when they earn a few thousand dollars over and above their pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the dinner break I was canvassing the problems that confront some 350,000 pensioners who this financial year will be faced with paying provisional tax. I pointed out that in 1984 some 240,000 pensioners were faced with that financial problem. One can quickly see how that figure has grown in a few years. It means that a massive percentage of the two million pensioners and veterans in this country now face double tax in the first year should they earn in excess of $1,000 over and above their pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has developed an historic reputation for his willingness to address problems, and I make a personal appeal that this problem be addressed also. The costs would not be great, and I will give the official figures. When the previous Government changed the threshold from $400 to $1,000 the cost was only $15m. I suppose that when one says that quickly it does not sound very much, and it is not much when we consider the number of people affected. I was told today that the cost of raising the threshold from $1,000 to $2,000 and thus exempting most of these people would be a mere $20m-I would think $20m well spent.

These people face a very specific problem. They have their money in fixed term investments and they suddenly receive a notice from the Australian Taxation Office advising them that they are required not only to pay tax on earnings over and above the threshold we have set-the pension plus the $1,000 rebate, or the $250 on $1,000 that pensioners have-but also to pay provisional tax. I ask that this matter be considered. Legislation would not be required to correct it. I have been informed that, under a general provision of the Income Assessment Act 1936, section 221yc (1) (a), the Commissioner has a discretionary power to set the limit, the threshold. So whilst this Government and this Parliament could urge it, the Commissioner could simply say, `I intend to raise that limit'. I make an appeal that that be done. I feel that many people out there who are pensioners and who do not have the financial capacity to meet the costs in the first year need to be relieved of that burden.

I believe that the limit should be raised in this way or, as an alternative, that the Act should be amended to exempt from the application of provisional tax those in receipt of a pension-a full pension if it has to be, although I would like to think a pension generally-and income from interest and dividends. As I said, in 1979 it cost $15m to raise the threshold from $400 to $1,000, and the estimated cost of raising it now to $2,000 is $20m. There are 350,000 pensioners and veterans looking to this Government for relief from what I believe is an iniquitous provision. I do not think it was ever meant to catch up these people. I do not think it was ever meant to get people on low incomes and fixed incomes, and say to them, `This year, when you have earned that extra $1,000, you will be double taxed'. That is in effect what happens.

We as a Labor Government have demonstrated a willingness to revamp the tax system. Full credit must go to the Treasurer and to our Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh, who has had a very difficult task in ensuring that we cut back on expenditure where it is wasted and that we improve our revenue base. I give full credit to the Prime Minister because he has given the lead in these things. He has given the lead in revamping the taxation system to give justice and fairness. I suggest that the two million pension recipients in this country would agree that a mere $20m would be money well spent. I make the appeal that I have made over two years-that the provisional tax provisions that apply to pensioners who earn over the $1,000 threshold be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to address the House tonight on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill. I will confine my comments essentially to the area of offshore banking. I am delighted to be able to do so, as I have a long personal history of working on the idea of developing offshore banking units in Australia. This goes back to a consultancy report I wrote in the late 1970s and early 1980s for the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in which I recommended such units. It is an issue that has received quite a lot of attention since then from the Campbell Committee; from the Martin Committee established by this Government; from a couple of State government committees, one of which, the Whitlam committee in New South Wales, I was associated with; and, finally, from the Commonwealth-State working party of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), of which I was also a member as a representative from Tasmania. The report of the latter Committee is the basis of the legislation before us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I am therefore pleased that we are finally seeing, after such an elongated process, some legislative initiative in this regard, although I have to express some disappointment that it is small and will probably prove to be insignificant.

I draw the attention of the House to the fact that this issue has quite often been broadened beyond offshore banking units, as it was in the case of the two State government studies, to look at the circumstances required to establish a financial centre in Australia. In those days there was some competition between Sydney and Melbourne for that purpose. Before I make some specific comments on the legislation, I would like to comment on some points made by other speakers in this debate from both sides of the House about the idea of legislation by Press release. I want to add my strength to the view that legislation by Press release is tending to get out of hand. The offshore banking issue is a very good example of that.

As I think back over the history of this technique, I guess legislation by Press release started back in the 1970s in the area of tax avoidance, where there was very little alternative. The Commissioner of Taxation was having trouble documenting and legislating against a lot of tax avoidance and evasion devices and techniques, and this became the most effective way of dealing with the problem. However, I suggest to the House that those days are substantially passed and that the extension of the practice of legislation by Press release into matters of considerable practical significance can cause unnecessary uncertainty on the part of businesses and private citizens who are trying to interpret their tax liability under foreshadowed pieces of legislation.

Let us look at the history of this piece of legislation in regard to offshore banking. The Treasurer's Commonwealth-State working party was set up in March 1984 and reported to him in August 1985. In July 1986, when the Australian dollar was under considerable pressure, the Treasurer announced for the first time his intention to bring down this sort of legislation. That was roughly 18 months ago. At that time he foreshadowed further consideration of the relevant legislative arrangements, which we had reported to us on 9 April 1987. Finally, the Bill itself appeared in the House in December of last year and is subject to debate at this time.

I can understand why the Treasurer tried to win the confidence of financial markets in July 1986, a period when, as I said, our exchange rate was under considerable pressure, but there seems to have been an unnecessary and undue period of delay. The Government foreshadowed legislation in this area in July 1986-as the second reading speech suggests, the legislation is to be effective from that date-but the legislation was not brought down until some 18 months later.

When I look back over the debate about the establishment of a financial centre in Australia and the key element of offshore banking units, my great disappointment is that we have not come nearly as far as we should have over that period. We have certainly made some substantial progress in deregulating our financial system and creating a lot of the circumstances in which we may emerge as a significant regional financial centre, but we are still a fair way short of that.

If we were at this point in time to do an objective assessment of Australia and its potential as a regional financial centre we would identify a number of very strong features in support of that case. In fact, we are now almost uniquely qualified in the Asia-Pacific region to play that sort of role. We have a time zone advantage relative to existing Asian financial centres, and dealers in Australia in their day to day dealing operations can effectively link with the east and west coasts of the United States of America and with major European centres in the course of their trading day. That is a very big advantage for a centre in this part of the world.

We also easily meet the basic language, accounting and legal infrastructure requirements for the development of such a centre in the international banking arena. We have a well-developed, competitive and open domestic financial system and the size of our domestic market is a pretty reasonable one by international standards. Our currency is also now widely traded in international markets and in 1987 we ranked at times as high as the fourth most significant currency in terms of daily turnover in international foreign exchange markets.

As a result of a lot of the deregulatory measures, we now no longer have any exchange controls, we have very high levels of representation by foreign banks and financial institutions, I think we have a reasonably sophisticated and experienced monetary authority in the Reserve Bank of Australia and we have a fairly well-developed tax surveillance infrastructure through the Australian Taxation Office. As I mentioned before, we have also had some political support, particularly from State governments-Mr Cain in Victoria and Mr Wran in New South Wales; interestingly both Australian Labor Party governments-in trying to develop the idea of establishing in Australia a financial centre for the Asia-Pacific time zone.

We can list all those facts but it obviously begs the question why it has not happened, particularly given the pace and the magnitude of some of the changes that have been made in our financial system in recent years. I suggest to the House that there are two or three main reasons why it has not happened. Most importantly, there has been a lack of will on the part of this Government to do anything about it. There is also unfortunately still a considerable amount of tunnel vision on the part of some Treasury officials as to the sort of role that such a centre could play and whether we should be part of this league or whether we should not and, of course, there is primarily the question of taxation, which is the key element of the legislation that is before us.

Consider the issue of taxation. Although today we see a financial system which is now fairly free, in terms of quantitative restrictions, interest rate ceilings and so on, but we still see a very cumbersome, ineffective and inefficient taxation of financial transactions in this country. So, while we have made a lot of progress in the formal deregulatory process, there is still a significant disadvantageous effect on the pattern of flows and the development of our financial system by the nature of taxation and the way it impacts on financial transactions. We have an interest withholding tax which is still quite significant, although, as I will mention in a moment, this legislation offers an exemption from that. We have a corporate tax rate that is at a staggeringly high level, an effectively high level, by Asian-Pacific standards; we have a host of other duties at difference levels in our system-financial institution duties, a bank account debits tax, stamp duties on various financial transactions, a number of loan instrument duties and so on.

In these terms then, I suggest that we have not gone very far down the offshore banking route, as this legislation deals with only one of those taxes of significance from the point of view of the development of an international financial system, namely, withholding tax, and it offers only a minuscule-I stress the word `minuscule'-exemption in the sense that it exempts only pure offshore banking transactions from the impact of that tax. They are international banking transactions among non-residents. This is disappointing at a time when much of the rest of the world is looking at the possibility of abolishing taxes such as interest withholding taxes. Do not get me wrong. I do not want to pooh-pooh the legislation completely; it is a step in the right direction but, as I have emphasised, it is very much a minuscule step.

If we want to take a realistic view of taxation in relation to this question of developing a financial centre in Australia, I suggest to the House that we have to look more broadly than at our own shores. We have to put ourselves in the international context and, particularly in our case, we have to compare ourselves with a number of the competing centres, either actual or potential, in the Asia-Pacific area. Specifically, I think we should look at Singapore and Hong Kong, both of which are well established regional financial centres; we should look at Tokyo, which is an emerging international financial centre; and we should also look across the Tasman to New Zealand where plans are apparently afoot in some quarters to establish Auckland or Wellington as an offshore banking centre. When we do that we find some fairly disturbing features from the point of view of our relative competitive position.

As far as offshore or international banking transactions go, both Singapore and Hong Kong substantially are without interest withholding taxes. Japan has significant exemptions, in its offshore banking market, from interest withholding taxes. Indeed, it is interesting to compare the growth of Singapore and Hong Kong, as two specific examples, in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It is significant to recognise that Hong Kong did not initially relax interest withholding tax in relation to these banking transactions and Singapore did. As a result in the early stages the Asian dollar market was located in Singapore and not Hong Kong. As I understand it, Hong Kong has subsequently recognised the error of its ways and has done something about those interest withholding taxes.

If we look at the corporate tax rates-some of my colleagues on both sides of the House mentioned these in earlier debate-we still see that we are at a significant disadvantage. Effectively, Hong Kong has a corporate tax rate of about 18 per cent; in Singapore it is about 33 per cent, compared with our 49 per cent. In fact, in Singapore there is a concessional profits tax on offshore banking business of only 10 per cent. If we look at Tokyo and if we look at distributed income we see the corporate tax rate there is 33 per cent, and on undistributed income 43 per cent. Of course, a number of people have mentioned New Zealand and the fact that it is about to establish a corporate tax rate of 28 per cent. In effectiveness terms I suggest that our excessive corporate tax rate is probably the principal reason why we have not emerged as a financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region.

For some reason there seems to be a blockage in the thinking of both this Government and the Treasury about the issue of taxation of financial transactions. We have read or have had trotted out to us on a number of occasions fairly spurious arguments in support of their position. A standard Treasury argument which appeared in the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System to some extent and also in the findings of the Treasurer's working party on offshore banking was that if we change the tax structure in relation to international banking in Australia we may divert resources from other activities when they are more efficiently utilised. This is generally the sort of argument that we hear from Treasury. It is a great furphy which is based on some fairly special academic theoretical assumptions that do not necessarily carry much weight or hold water in our very imperfect world. Of course, the fact remains that we could actually attract resources to Australia from the rest of the world if we were to adopt the appropriate taxation structure.

We also quite often hear stories coming from Treasury that we should not unnecessarily subsidise particular industries or activities, which always makes me baulk because we already subsidise so many industries or activities in Australia in one way or another. But even if a correct view, this would not work against the logic of simply cutting the corporate tax rate across the board. I would also recognise that on occasions governments have used differential tax rates to stimulate particular sectors and particular activities for other than economic reasons, in particular social or political reasons. I suggest to the House that our existing taxation structure is counterproductive to the development of an international financial centre in Australia; it discourages the development of that centre.

Quite often we also hear the argument from Treasury officials and others that we will forgo revenue if we give up some of these transactions taxes. The fact is that a lot of these transactions are being organised in Australia but they are not taxes being booked here or are not being done here at all, because of the nature of our tax regime. So it is not certain, when we free up that regime, that we will not stimulate more activity and thereby increase our tax revenue, rather than lose it. I suggest in fairly crude terms that if we get 10 per cent or 20 per cent of something it is better than getting 49 per cent of nothing, which is essentially the current situation.

We often also hear concerns expressed by the Commissioner of Taxation about the possibility of this sort of market and proposed taxation arrangements furthering tax avoidance. It is a serious problem and not one that we want to treat lightly. But I suggest to the Commissioner that there is quite a lot of international tax management beyond the purview of the Australian taxation authorities at present and I am not sure that the development of an offshore banking centre in Australia would make avoidance any worse; indeed it would probably make it better. If the Commissioner is on his toes he would be able to establish a tax surveillance network which he does not presently have or a better one than he presently has.

The final argument we usually hear is that we have missed our chance in establishing a financial centre in Australia. Singapore and Hong Kong are really well established, Tokyo is opening up and we will be very much Johnny-come-latelies to this business. It is the same argument as people used against financial sector deregulation as a whole and I do not think anyone would dispute the benefits of that process today. It is also the same argument used five or six years ago about competing with Singapore or Hong Kong.

I suggest to the House that we should consider what has happened to those two financial centres in recent times. There is no time like the present to further our endeavours in this regard. Take Singapore for example. A lot of the gloss of that country's early success has now been lost in the aftermath of what has been a fairly poorly managed economy. The exchange rate has been held at an overvalued level and the monetary authorities have been unbelievably intrusive in dealing with international financial transactions. And there is always the possibility in the future of political instability in that country associated with the transition from Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew to whomever it may be, even if it is his son.

Others may argue that Hong Kong is extremely well established and that we will not be able to take away any of its competitive edge. But the future of that country is not clear either. The uncertainty about the lease in Hong Kong remains. We do not know what will happen when sovereignty passes to the Chinese in 1997. Also anyone who wants to see how strong Hong Kong is today in the post-stock market crash environment should visit that city which has been really shaken as a financial centre as a result of the crash. Finally, the issue is not simply one of whether or not we are competitive. In theory-if correctly stated-an additional financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region can be a plus anyway as it deepens the inter-bank market and enables a greater spreading of risk in this region.

So, to summarise, I welcome the pieces of this legislation that relate to offshore banking and the fact that there is an interest withholding tax exemption to encourage the development of this sort of transaction in Australia. But as is so typical of this Government, it is far too little far too late in terms of getting us on the way to being a significant financial centre. We can easily be a significant financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region but this calls for considerably greater political will than we have seen from this Government, a much greater commitment to a rationalisation and improvement of the tax structure and, in particular, a lowering of the corporate tax rate by this Government.

I am fascinated by the number of occasions on which I have heard senior Ministers of this Government lecture us all about the need to diversify our export base and to develop service sector exports and so on. Here is a unique opportunity in the financial sector to develop alternative exports. I think it just calls for a more realistic assessment of what needs to be done in order to achieve that result. I look forward from today to a situation where, if the appropriate taxation policies are adopted-and I am not talking about wildly concessional ones which will benefit a few, but appropriate restructuring of taxation-there could well be at the turn of the century two major financial centres in the Asia-Pacific region. Those two centres could be Tokyo, which is moving quite quickly towards that objective at the Northern Hemisphere end of the Asia-Pacific region, and Australia at the bottom end with both Singapore and Hong Kong being markedly less significant centres as we look forward over that sort of time horizon. But this will not happen on its own; it will not happen unless the Government overcomes its blind spot on genuine tax reform.

I was fascinated to hear a number of speakers tonight-we have consistently heard this-talk about what a great tax reformer this Government is. In fact, one of the speakers said that they are probably the greatest tax reforming government in the history of the world. I suggest to the House that that is absolute nonsense. I refer the House to what happened in 1985. A unique opportunity in the political and economic circumstances that existed at that time to reform taxation was squandered by this Government which demonstrated its inability to come to grips with genuine tax reform. All we got was more taxes, new taxes and a higher overall tax burden. That sort of attitude and mentality, carried through to the financial system, will ensure that Australia does not reach its full potential as a significant financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I think the House is better for the very thoughtful contribution from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) who, of course, is acknowledged for his expertise in this area. However, I would say to him that if he believes that 1985 represented a unique opportunity for tax reform in this country, he has a very short memory. The events of 1985 were precipitated by this Government and significant tax reform resulted from the Tax Summit. I would say that probably 1979, when the Fraser Government had the huge advantages of the oil price shock and a significant majority in both Houses of this Parliament, represented a much better opportunity for tax reform. But this opportunity was passed by.

SPEECH.PARA: I also find it amazing that the honourable member should stand in this place and, at the same time as talking about the speed of change, criticise the Government for the use of Press releases for announcing changes within the tax system. I would think that if we waited for legislation to pass through the Houses of the Parliament we would be waiting much longer for change. I find some inconsistency in the arguments of the honourable member who comes from and represents that side of the House which was notable for its lethargy and immobility in tax reform during its last seven years of government. Of course, the Opposition's spokesman on taxation matters, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), got up and said, predictably, that this is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. I always wonder when I hear that said, what in fact people mean. Of course, next year if there is economic growth the Government will be the highest taxing government. The year after that, if there is economic growth, the Government again will be the highest taxing government. I really think rather superficial terminology is used in this respect. What is important is that in 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88 there was a significant fall in outlays, something which has not traditionally occurred in Budgets in this country. Indeed, this is an example of the fiscal responsibility that this Government has been able to show.

Of course, the most masterful contribution to this debate came from the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred) who said very correctly and sensibly, when talking about an article which appeared in the Canberra Times today, that the nominal rate of tax was not the actual rate of tax which was paid. The honourable member was correct in saying that. He made the point that some companies in this country pay very reasonable rates of taxation and others generally seem to pay very small amounts of taxation. That, of course, is related to particular circumstances which arise from year to year-perhaps the debt burden, the nature of activities or losses in a particular year.

The honourable member for Bruce made the very mischievous suggestion that the companies which paid the lowest amounts of tax were under the control of friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and that in some way the Prime Minister and his mates were benefiting from the inequities of the system which had been put in place by this Government. Of course, that is absolute ridiculous nonsense. Indeed, if one looks at the list of lowest tax paying companies one finds mention of Elders IXL. I suppose the suggestion is that in fact John Elliott is in some way a friend of the Prime Minister. If he were a friend of the Prime Minister, there is no way in which he would be undermining the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) at the moment because it would be in our interests for him to be secure in his position. Indeed, the activity in which Mr Elliott is presently involved would not be occurring.

I found it even more amazing that, having said that the nominal rate is not the actual rate, the honourable member for Bruce then moved on to the circumstances that exist in England and the United States of America in terms of the nominal rate of tax that exists in those countries. The honourable member made no mention of the consumption tax that is imposed in the United States or other factors that operate. If it is the case that the honourable member for Bruce sees the Thatcher Government as being a model of fiscal responsibility and tax reform, he should have sat with me a few years ago when I saw Margaret Thatcher arguing for a fringe benefits tax, for an entertainment tax and for an end to the free lunch. While I may not be a philosophical supporter of Margaret Thatcher's views, her consistency and her philosophical integrity are things which are not seen in the Opposition in this place. It is all very well to compare ourselves with the United States, but the honourable member for Bruce should go to people in his electorate who are suffering from chronic disease or who are in need of health care and say, `What we want is a tax rate consistent with that which exists in the United States, but unfortunately you are going to have to pay massive amounts for health care over a long time'. Here again, the philosophical integrity of members of the Opposition is strained.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987 and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987 give effect to a number of Government policy decisions announced during 1986 and 1987 and amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The measures include encouragement of the development of offshore banking in Australia through the withholding tax exemption for interest paid to non-residents by the offshore banking units. In his exposition the honourable member for Wentworth covered very fully the need for these changes. Additionally, these measures provide for capital gains tax roll-over relief-that is, deferral of liability for certain reorganisations of resident unit trusts. The Bills also contain measures announced in January 1987 to amend the law relating to tax on lump sum superannuation and kindred payments. These measures are to remedy shortcomings in the law which have been exploited in order to defeat the Government's objectives in the retirement income area. In the retirement income area the Government's direction has been to discourage people from taking lump sums which are then spent or frittered away, thus causing those people to become social security recipients. Of course, there are a number of other amendments contained in the legislation, including the removal of special concessional treatment for expenditure on building for scientific research and other research and development purposes. All these measures are directed to the use of revenue in a more productive and innovative way.

What can be said about this legislation is that it gives further effect to the tax reform program that the Hawke Government has undertaken. It gives further effect to increasing the fairness, equity and efficiency of our taxation system. The need to distribute the burden more equally and the need for investment to be more productive and efficient is recognised.

It has been said many times-and I well remember the debates on the entertainment tax-that our restaurant industry would be destroyed by the Government's initiatives in that area. Yet year after year we see increasing numbers of people being employed in that area. We heard that the motor vehicle industry needed to be underwritten by the fringe benefits tax, but our initiatives in that area and, indeed, the improvement of the substantiation requirements have allowed for fair deductions. However, for those who were taking unfair advantage there is some sort of necessary scrutiny of their activities. Indeed, as a medical practitioner, I thought it absolutely absurd that one should be able to claim as a tax deduction 100 per cent of one's motor vehicle use plus a percentage of the vehicle use of one's spouse. Those sorts of rorts have been removed.

Of course, the tax reform program of this Government has been fairly wide ranging, but it is Opposition members who, after 7 1/2 years in government, left us with a rate of 60c in the dollar. Yet in this debate they have been saying how terrible it is that the rate should be 49c in the dollar. After 7 1/2 years and every opportunity to reform taxation in this country, with some windfall benefits and opportunities because of a majority in both houses of Parliament, these people did not take that opportunity.

Many of the decisions taken by this Government were not easy and were not particularly popular. The tax on lump sum superannuation was a long term measure that we believed, over time, would change the emphasis in that area. Indeed, it was not popular; but the Government took it on the chest and made that decision. Our initiatives with the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the entertainment tax-those base broadening measures that we undertook-were not rabbit-in-the-hat measures; they were long term moves to change and broaden the base of taxation in this country.

For the business community there was full imputation and removal of double taxation on dividends, freeing up of the financial institutions, freeing up of the financial sector, the entry of foreign banks and the floating of the Australian dollar. All these initiatives, many of them not easy decisions, are part of the mosaic of tax reform that this Government has undertaken. But the Opposition continues to be populist. The latest figure that it is talking about is $11 billion worth of spending cuts through the 1990s. In the House yesterday we heard the Prime Minister challenge the Leader of the Opposition on his figures. The Leader of the Opposition is denying it but once again, as in the election campaign in the middle of last year, we have talk of massive cuts in expenditure but no details.

One only has to remember the election platform of the Liberal Party of Australia seven months ago, the approaches made to the electorate, the changes that it was going to bring about but, unfortunately, what we had were unfunded tax cuts and spurious expenditure cuts which were never identified. John Elliott, whom I have mentioned earlier in this debate, said that the Liberals did not deserve to win; that they were not ready to win. Indeed, the dazzling array of promises that we heard, the tax cuts which we could not afford, all the problems that these may have brought and the huge credibility gap that was discovered in the Opposition's policy brought about its defeat at that election.

The latest endorsement by the Opposition is even more interesting because of the present situation in which we find ourselves. On AM on 11 February the Leader of the Opposition generally endorsed the New Zealand tax package-a shining and superficial package, I suggest. In that program John Howard clearly endorsed the general thrust of that policy and said:

I . . . repeat that we were going precisely down the right track last July in the taxation policy that we presented, and what has happened since has validated that approach and has made the criticism of that policy by the Government and many people in the media wrong.

He is saying that the path taken by New Zealand is the path that he suggested in July last year; indeed, that the policy approach that was taken by his Party at that time has been validated by the moves in New Zealand.

Let us look at the elements of the New Zealand package. We find the cancellation of deductibility from personal income tax of donations to charities-something, I imagine, that would be very popular in the electorate! I am sure that all those people working for voluntary and charity organisations would be interested to know that these are ways in which the Liberal Party will be funding future tax cuts. Other measures are the taxing of income received by charities on their own investment, a 24 per cent tax on employer contributions to superannuation funds and a 25 per cent tax on earnings of those funds. With the debate on superannuation continuing, the Leader of the Opposition has endorsed tax cuts for business funded by increased superannuation charges for employer contributions and for the earnings of those funds in New Zealand. There are also tougher substantiation rules in New Zealand and, again, all we have heard since the introduction of fringe benefit tax is how terrible the substantiation rules are. In New Zealand the substantiation rules are tougher, yet they are being endorsed by the Leader of the Oppostion.

Last on the list, but perhaps most important, is a 10 per cent consumption tax in New Zealand. Is it the case that once again the Leader of the Opposition will be pushing that barrow? Australia is in a critical process of adjustment. We cannot afford the populism of the Opposition; we cannot afford the costs of the Opposition's promises. If it is going to cut revenue, cut rates, abolish the assets test, cut out lump sum tax on superannuation, abolish the fringe benefits tax and bring back the free lunch, it has to say how it will do it. If it is going to introduce the consumption tax, it should let us know about it. If there are to be massive expenditure cuts, let it tell the pensioners what will happen to their pensions. If there are to be decreases in education, health and other areas, it should say so. If it will not say so, what it is saying is nonsense. The situation will be as it was in July last year, and as it always is-the sums do not, and will not, add up. If the Opposition is going to offer-as has been offered in New Zealand-decreases in business tax, funded by a 10 per cent consumption tax, we need to know. If the Opposition, is to offer decreases in business taxation by taxing superannuation contributions and funds' profits, let it say so. But let us not hear Opposition members bleating from the other side of the House about what the Australian Labor Party might do when, at the same time, they are endorsing proposals which are occurring in New Zealand and which contain many of those measures. The measures that the Government has introduced in this Bill give effect to a vast mosaic of tax reform; the Bill provides for reform which is fair and just. Until the Opposition can provide a credible alternative, it will have scant respect in this place or outside.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 16, 17, 18 and 19 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) will lead to a tightening of the screw. The Prime Minister is also the managing director of Australia and is responsible and answerable in these areas. But today he refused point-blank to give an answer. Government back bench members-who have little say in this matter because they get these things served up to them from their executive and who have lost control of Caucus that was once theirs-come into the House and say, `The Opposition should tell us what it intends to do'. These Bills are about tax, deal with a multitude of bandaids to the tax system and address the problems principally in legislation only recently introduced. One would have thought that the Government could have got the legislation right the first time around. This legislation also addresses problems which have been identified by the Opposition. It is tax, tax, tax. Frequently debate in this place, as reflected in the remarks of the honourable member for Perth, turns to how we are taxed. The honourable member wants to raise the spectre of a consumption tax. Reference was made to the Government's wonderful decision to float the dollar. The Government came to office in 1983, and one could scour its policy from end to end without finding any reference to floating the dollar. The Government never thought of it. In fact, had it thought of it, it would have thought it a scandal. It was regulatory and it was not going to do it. It is time this Government of self-congratulation was prepared to stand up and tell it as it is. I think it is time we accepted that the tax laws of Australia have some limit on the Government's share. It is worth noting in terms of government revenues that in 1950 the governments of Australia managed to run this country on 15 per cent of gross domestic product-15 per cent of our national productivity. Those governments took people's income in January and February and it left the rest to them. Today those governments collectively are taking nearly 44 per cent. In other words, we are fast approaching the point where we have to work six months of the year for the Government before there is any return for ourselves. It is not right for the honourable member for Perth and others to scoff at an Opposition that goes to the people and says: `We will accept the discipline of lower revenue. Take it from me, those queues the Government tries to explain away are not explained away by Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance.
