TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the opportunity of taking part in this debate to look at two aspects of our taxation law. One is the way in which this present Government has increased the level of taxation paid by ordinary Australian taxpayers, particularly ordinary Australian taxpaying families with dependent children. Secondly, I want to spend some time looking at the whole question of tax concessions currently available for superannuation and the alarm that has been caused by actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government in unsettling people who are approaching retirement age and who do not know what action to take.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, to turn to the way in which this Government has taxed Australian families: two years ago, in 1986, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) came into this House and announced a tax package which, he said, would make fundamental changes in the Australian taxation system. Changes it made, but equity it did not achieve. In fact, the system was made more inequitable as a consequence of the Labor Party Government's tax reforms.

Let us look at some of the facts. When the Labor Party came to office the spouse rebate for a family where the spouse was dependent and had in her care dependent children was $1,030. In 1988, under the Labor Party tax policy that spouse rebate is still only $1,030. Its spending power has been considerably reduced as a consequence of inflation. In fact, Australian families-those with dependent children and those where households have only a dependent spouse-are paying $320m towards the excesses of Labor Government mismanagement of this economy. If the spouse rebate had been indexed in the way in which I have described, the amount by which the tax burden on families with dependent spouses would have been reduced would have been $320m.

Worse still, the family allowances that were available to families in 1983, when the Labor Party came to office, have been fixed, too, in money terms-no variation whatsoever. The cost to those Australian families with dependent children has been of the order of $1.1 billion. Although tax rates may appear to have been reduced-I shall come to that in a moment-the fact is that Australian families have lost relativity: they are relatively more heavily taxed today than they were when the Labor Party came to office.

The Labor Party has demonstrated that it is not concerned about the economic well-being of Australian families. Indeed, for those families which happen for the moment to have a high income the universality of the family allowance has been abolished. If the income is above a certain level, no family allowance is payable. The only concession that a family with an income above that means test threshold gets because there are young children in the family, if it has a single income, is $200 tax rebate, the additional amount added to the spouse rebate over the basic $830 that is available for a dependent spouse only.

To suggest that a family supporting one, two, or three children and with a high income should be paying exactly the same amount of tax as a single taxpayer with the same income is a failure to understand how a tax system should be adjusted to be sensitive to the whole question of capacity to pay. Capacity to pay is not merely a function of the size of income; capacity to pay is a function of the number of people dependent upon the household income. On other occasions I have stated that I believe that allowances for dependants-dependent children and dependent spouses-should be set at the same level as the government would have to pay if the taxpayer were not supporting that dependant. That then would achieve equity and proper relativity between taxpayers who are single and taxpayers who are supporting dependent spouses and dependent children.

Some will say, `I am single and why should I be paying for other people's children?'. Not so! The fact is that we should be looking at our tax system on a life cycle approach. The great maj- ority of Australian taxpayers have periods of time when they are single. They have periods of time when they are married and have no dependent spouse because their spouse is working. They have other periods in their life cycle when they have a dependent spouse. Furthermore, there are times during their life cycle when they have children dependent upon them.

We should look at the rebates that we give to families with children and dependent spouses on that basis, as a life cycle adjustment to take account of the reduced capacity to pay on the part of the taxpayers who are supporting dependants who, if they are abandoned, become a charge on the general body of taxpayers, in any event, at a much higher rate. It would be much better if the tax system were adjusted in a more sensitive fashion.

I said that the Labor Party attempted to create the illusion that there was a reduction in tax for the average Australian. It is just not so, because under the Fraser Government the underlying basic rate of tax was 30c in the dollar. If one's income then was substantially in excess of average weekly earnings, something like 30 or 40 per cent above average weekly earnings, one moved into a higher tax bracket of 40c in the dollar or whatever it was. The Labor Party, just as it has done with the spouse rebates and just as it has done with family allowances, has frozen the tax thresholds and, as a result, bracket creep has taken place. Now taxpayers move into the 40c in the dollar rate at a level of income significantly below average weekly earnings. They move into that bracket when their incomes exceed $19,500, whereas if that threshold had been indexed they would not move into that tax rate unless their income was approaching $30,000 in 1988 dollars.

Let us just look at some of the figures. One finds that, since Labor came to office, average weekly earnings have risen from $370 to $505 a week, a 36.6 per cent increase in income. What has happened to net tax payable after making allowance for pay as you earn (PAYE) tax, the Medicare levy, rebates for dependent spouses and expenditure rebates that used to be available under the Fraser Government? We find that tax under the Fraser Government, expressed in the dollars of the year, would have been $2,998 in March 1983, but on the average weekly earnings in 1988 the tax burden would be $5,848.

One may say that that is fine, but that the dollar values are different now. Let us examine the percentage change. For a single-income household on average weekly earnings, it is an increased tax burden of 95 per cent in contrast to an increase in the money wages of something less than 36 or 37 per cent. Increasing numbers of Australians are moving into the higher income tax bracket and now a substantial proportion of the full time work force is paying 40c in the dollar rather than something like 30c in the dollar. In effect, the basic standard rate tax applicable to the full time work force has been increased by the Labor Party by 33 1/3 per cent, from 30c to 40c.

This is having a very serious effect on Australian families and households, because not only are they sharing their burden that is arising as a consequence of wage restraint measures, but families with children and dependent spouses are being hit as well by Labor's increased tax burden, while those on very high incomes are being given substantial tax cuts. They may deserve them. There may be a need for a greater incentive and greater reward for effort for high income people, but we need to make adjustments to the tax system in a manner that is fair and equitable to Australian families. The Labor Government has utterly failed Australian families in this regard, for if they were to be put in a situation where they had the same real resources available to them this year as they had in 1983, they would need an after tax increase in their incomes of at least $42 a week if they were on average weekly earnings.

I turn now to the question of superannuation, because this Bill contains some tidying up measures in relation to the Labor Party's approach to the taxation of lump sum payments. A very difficult question exists in relation to Australia's retirement income policy because the whole system is an utter failure. People are double dipping; they are getting tax encouragement to provide for retirement. When they reach retirement they have spent the resources in respect of which they received tax exemption in one form or another or, when they reach retirement, they then set about spending it. Therefore, they have had a tax advantage during their working life-or their employers have-and when they reach retirement those people turn to the social security system and seek a social security pension.

Members of the House would be fully aware that, in Australia today, our social security program provides a substantial proportion of income to at least 80 per cent of people of pensionable age; the superannuation provision provides a very much smaller percentage with a significant proportion of income; and the private provision provides yet a smaller percentage. As honourable members would recall, I have long been, and continue to be, an advocate for the total abolition not only of the assets test but also of the income test. This is because 80 per cent of the retired population are already dependent upon the age pension. If the test were abolished I believe people would behave in a more rational fashion. They would invest their money to yield the highest income. As a result of that the Government would gather in increased taxation. If pensions were paid to those who are not now in receipt of pensions because of assets or income, at least one-third, and probably 40 per cent of it, would come back in the form of taxation, because pensions are taxable.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, give the millionaires a pension?

—Yes, millionaires would get it, too, because it would be much better if as a consequence of the need to pay those pensions, we placed on millionaires a higher level of income tax and had a better and fairer system. The Government has built the most unfair system of retirement incomes imaginable. However, one could consider the whole question of superannuation tax shelters. It is the largest fringe benefit that remains available to the Australian taxpayers. Are they taking advantage of it? They certainly are, and they are doing so in a way that is not achieving the policy objective that all would believe it should have: that is, that when people reach retirement they will have a lessened reliance on the social security system.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of ways of doing that. One could say, `All right, Ian Wilson, member for Sturt, if you intend to abolish the assets and income tests, maybe you should say that there should not be a tax shelter at all in respect of superannuation, whether it is the tax exempt nature of the contribution of the employer or the tax exempt nature of the employer's contribution that is seen to be part of the wages of the employee, whether it is the income on the funds that is tax sheltered to a substantial and significant degree, or whether it is the generous tax opportunities that relate to the payment of the benefit, not at retirement but very often 10 years before retirement, to create the opportunity for the double dipping when one reaches the accepted pensionable age.

One solution to this whole problem could well be to leave those tax shelters as they are rather than to abolish them, and to have a consistent framework of retirement income provision. As I said, one could approach it by saying that if one provides universal pensions paid for by all taxpayers, including millionaires, who pay their taxes, one should not have tax shelters for superannuation, the beneficiaries of which are largely the millionaires, who are having massive amounts of income tax-sheltered for them in a manner which gives them tax sheltered savings, tax sheltered income on those savings and tax sheltered benefits when they ultimately take the money out.

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is concerned about millionaires and the equity of this system for them. Has he studied the extent to which the present superannuation concessions favour those who can most easily afford to put a huge amount of their discretionary income into tax sheltered funds? As I said, one could have a universal pension and abolish the tax sheltering, but that would cause a substantial unsettling of the superannuation, insurance and savings industries. Therefore, the solution could well be to abolish the assets and income tests in respect of all assets and all income of retirees, except for tax sheltered income and assets. Therefore, we would leave the tax concessions: if one has the tax concessions through one's superannuation fund directly or indirectly, when one reaches retirement, the solution could then be that the benefits received by way of income or capital at the time of retirement-age 65 would be my preference-be subject to a pension benefits test that should apply only to previously tax sheltered pension benefits. The present assets and income tests could apply. One could have $10 worth of assets representing $1 of income, and each dollar of deemed income reducing the entitlement to pension at the rate of 50c in the dollar. That would then eliminate the double dipping. It would give people a choice. They could save through a tax-sheltered superannuation scheme and have their pension subjected to a superannuation benefits test. Alternatively, they could save without tax sheltering, in which case they should be able in retirement to receive their full income from their savings and investments and at the same time continue to be entitled to an age pension. In that way we would introduce equity into the system.

Furthermore, I think we should study the whole question of the extent to which tax concessions should be unlimited. I spoke earlier in this debate about the extent to which people on very high incomes are taking advantage of this tax sheltering. We should work out what is a fair thing. Do we want an income-related superannuation scheme encouraged through tax sheltering, or do we want a flat rate scheme related to average weekly earnings? I prefer the latter. I think people should be allowed to engage in tax sheltering to the extent of, say, four times average weekly earnings over a lifetime, with perhaps a cap of 10 per cent of average weekly earnings each year.

But this is part of the rational debate, not of the unsettling features that have come about because the Prime Minister has said, `We are looking at it. We may make changes and we may not'. The least thing the Prime Minister should tell those approaching retiring age is that he will not introduce any scheme that is retrospective. People who are approaching retirement are fearful that the savings they have made in the past under the system that then applied, giving them tax exemption, will be adversely and prejudicially taxed as a consequence of changes to be made by the Government. Changes made in a retrospective fashion should not be permitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard what the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) said. I think his contribution to the debate was thoughtful and sensible. In the context of the sort of debate we are having here tonight, it needs to be recognised that the whole question of retirement incomes and an appropriate taxation scheme is one that the Australian community at large is concerned about. I make two observations about the difficulties we had when we came into Government. First, there was a loss of confidence in the taxation system on the part of the community. I do not want to make a heavy political point about that, but I think some of the avoidance and evasion practices that had emerged had resulted in a loss of confidence in the taxation system. Secondly, in relation to the honourable member's point about retirement provisions, there had been a substantial ageing of the Australian population, which is bunching up year by year. It is also true of Japan and other countries that we have visited.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the observation that when, on the one hand, we have a taxation system which needs some amendments and, on the other hand, there has been a change in the demographic structure of the Australian population, we need to take some steps. I think the honourable member for Sturt would concede that we began to look at the tax system because it was clear to many of us, not just on this side but in the Parliament as a whole, that some avoidance and evasion had been practised. So we commenced a process of taxation reform. At the same time, it was evident that if we were to try to reduce the deficit in this community-that was a common problem for everyone-it was necessary at least to try to target our welfare spending. It was not without controversy, but we set about that process. A substantial element of that process was the assets test. As I said it was not without controversy, but I think it can be said that the assets test was really about targeting limited resources to those most in need, and I shall come back to a couple of points the honourable member made earlier.

We also felt that in terms of pensions it was very important not only to spend money in areas of need but also to raise money through the tax system in a way that was regarded as both efficient and equitable. I think some of the taxation reforms we made really meet those criteria of being efficient, equitable and so on. But it is also true to say that if one looks over time at a tax system-and we are doing that; we are in the process of looking at our tax system and have been doing so in fact since 1983-one finds that in a community like Australia, being a country open to lots of information, which gets expert advice and which tries to plan its income and expenditure activities, areas like superannuation are the ones that legitimately a government should look at in terms of how it might change the taxation treatment of superannuation.

One thing we have done is begin to deal with the whole question of lump sum superannuation, because it was the view of the Government that the taking of annuities was an important step because we did not want people double dipping. That is why we have taken that step. Again, like the assets test, it was not without some pain; it was not without some political discomfort. But the observation could be made that, taking a long view-and it is difficult with three-year parliaments to take a long view-if our concern is with the deficit and with the structure of government spending and revenue, both the assets test decision and the decision on lump sum superannuation were decisions that in light of experience were merited because we were trying to target both our welfare spending and also limit the double dipping aspects of super- annuation.

I ought also observe for the honourable member for Sturt that this process has not continued for the obvious reason that in the area of superannuation there has clearly been a greater resort to superannuation by the Australian community, and part of that is very commendable. The aspect that is commendable is that clearly people are preparing and spending for their own retirement; they are apportioning income for their own retirement. But it is also true-and I heard what the honourable member said about tax shelters-that we ought to be in a position from time to time to make a judgment and ask whether the tax benefit incurred as a result of an activity is disproportionate in terms of the amount that ultimately would be gained as a result of that superannuation activity. Right at the moment, to be fair to the honourable member for Sturt, I am not making a decision on that, but it is also fair to say that that is the sort of situation that should arise at this stage.

I also heard how the honourable member might deal with that and how he might ultimately treat these amounts when they are realised later on. He made a thoughtful contribution. He suggested that if things are subject to a tax shelter at the time of their being acquired, they might well be treated differentially to those not subject to a tax shelter. That is a sensible contribution, but when we are talking to the Australian community in general we have to establish in their minds one or two principles. The first is the one I referred to earlier: it is clear that if the nature of the Australian population changes, if the population ages, we will have to target our welfare spending much more. We could get into a big debate, obviously, about the assets test and its political consequences, but it would be observed by a number of people watching Australia that we do have to spend pension funds where they are most needed. The Japanese really have a big problem in this area, and I think many other economies will face this situation down the track.

The second principle is: if we have a structure which is providing for retirement, have we thought that structure through both in terms of the ultimate benefit to be gained from superannuation activity and also in terms of the tax treatment of that superannuation activity? It is true to say right at the moment that we have examined that. We have examined it once in terms of the lump sum superannuation payment and we are examining it again in terms of the tax treatment of superannuation. It is also true to say that clearly people in the community are uncertain. Anyone who has taken superannuation or who is contributing to superannuation wants to know what he is getting out of it. I observe, by the by, that I think the change in the stock market activity last year has meant there has also been great activity in terms of superannuation benefits because clearly many companies, such as the Australian Mutual Provident Society, have suffered a substantial loss in their portfolio investments and in other areas. That has ultimately had consequences for many people in the Australian community. It is not something we take joy in, and I know that the honourable member for Sturt and others do not take joy in it, but it is true that we are in a volatile situation in terms of what might be ultimately realised. It is also true to say that we would be avoiding our responsibility as a government if we did not look seriously at the consequences of our taxation treatment of superannuation, rather than just labelling things and saying this is a rort and this is a ramp, but simply saying that this is a fair and equitable distribution.

I heard what the honourable member for Sturt said earlier in his contribution about whether or not superannuation funds have benefited from tax shelters since their inception and how he would treat them ultimately. I recognise that point but I say to the honourable member that I think the process we are going through is a necessary one. If we were to examine other economies such as Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States of America and New Zealand, we would find the same sorts of questions coming up, not because of who is currently in power but simply because of the economic realities of the circumstance. The honourable member should deal with that as we are dealing with it. We are recognising that we have a tax question-I dealt with this earlier-where we had tax avoidance and evasion activity. I could talk further about that but I will not in this debate. We have that question, we also have a change in the actuarial or demographic structure of the population and we then have to try to make optimal decisions.

I think the view that we ought to be putting to the Australian community is that we are conscious, as a government, that we ought to be aware of the sorts of returns that people want from their superannuation policies. We are also conscious of the fact that tax treatment is important. It is also important to observe that we have been conscious that this country has sadly lacked a national superannuation scheme. I am not talking necessarily in terms of the national superannuation scheme that might have been endorsed 20 or 30 years ago but I think we are conscious of the fact that because we have supported the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its move for industry superannuation we really need to try to encourage more and more people to provide for their retirement. That really brings me back to the centrepiece of this debate. As a community we need to recognise that fact.

If we were to go back 40 years to 1948 and make one observation it would be that one of the great problems we did not tackle, except peripherally at that time, was that we did not have a national superannuation scheme, covering the whole community, and the consequences to the population as a whole are now becoming evident. My friend the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and my friend the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) would recognise that we are facing the consequences of not having a national superannuation scheme then and having an ageing population now. Opposition members and Government members are all stuck with the consequences of trying to provide for an ageing population. We understand very clearly that simply trying to provide for it out of Consolidated Revenue is a bit like a dog chasing its tail and I think that is conceded.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are going to run out of tail.

—I thank the honourable member for Wide Bay because that is true; we are going to run out of tail. So we have to try to make decisions. I know it is very easy in the context of debate in this place to come into the House, make a series of political points and win the day but when we finish that day we are still stuck with an economy in which we have diminishing resources, enormous problems to deal with in terms of allocating those resources, and a commitment to try to provide for those areas of need. I say to honourable members opposite and to colleagues on my side of the House that that problem will not go away; it is a problem that we have to continue to address.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give one example of how that problem demonstrates itself. I know that many pensioners who receive the full range of fringe benefits in some circumstances are well catered for because they are now at about 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and they were at 22.8 per cent in 1983. But I think it would be recognised by members opposite, as it has been recognised by members on this side of the House, that sometimes superannuants who are on very modest superannuation when they retire and who do not have fringe benefits can, in a relative sense, be worse off vis-a-vis pensioners. The community should consider whether we should offer those superannuants the option of a senior citizen's card which would give them a modest range of fringe benefits, particularly things such as transport concessions in the State systems; entrance to entertainment venues, such as cinemas; entrance to sporting events, such as cricket, football and so on; and also some minor concessions from Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —A phasing out system would be helpful too, rather than sudden death.

—I think that is correct. We should look at exactly that. I commend the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) because I think he has recognised that. Prior to the Parliament getting up last year we dealt with one or two such issues. One of those involved what we called the Santa Clause or Father Christmas dilemma. Because of a decision by the Federal Court people were no longer able to average income over the year; it had to be treated as being received in a short period. To the credit of the Minister and the Government they have taken action in this regard. This takes up the point the honourable member was making: it is essential that there is a phasing in system. Many people experience great stress if they think they will lose their fringe benefits. Honourable members will understand that such stress is an extraordinary burden. We recognise that and I am sure the honourable member for Sturt does. Many people receiving modest superannuation pensions also experience those difficulties. Over time the Federal and State governments should work towards providing a minimum range of such benefits to those receiving modest superannuation payments as well as to those receiving the pension.

SPEECH.PARA: In concluding my remarks I come back to emphasise two or three points. Firstly, we have been trying to modernise and make more effective the taxation system. That process is continuing. Secondly, we have tried to target our expenditure in welfare areas. I have acknowledged that this has not been without controversy but I think at the end of the day it has been recognised that we have made the right decisions. Thirdly, as the nature of superannuation changes from time to time, the Government's treatment of the taxation aspects of superannuation may need to change. I recognise that may produce uncertainty, but we on this side of the House recognise that we have a responsibility in terms not only of our budgetary considerations but also our provisions for retirement. I say clearly to the Australian community that we are conscious of all those factors when we make decisions as a Government. It is very easy to score points in this place in Question Time and debates and so on but at the end of the day honourable members-whether it be the honourable member for Wide Bay or me-are stuck with a responsibility to the wider community. We must recognise the actuarial structure of the community, the ageing process that has gone on and the limited resources we have to meet the needs. I think with good sense and a commitment to principles that can be argued and worked through in the Australian community we can make the right decisions. I am confident that in 10 years time when we look back we will say that in the processes that are going on now we were prepared to make difficult decisions that were right in the long term even though they were not immediately popular. I am pleased to commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) and the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill that have been put forward by the honourable member for Kooyong and Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and also support, as his amendments do, the second reading of these two pieces of legislation. In doing so I would like to make two points. I would like to make a point about the approach of the Australian Labor Party Government to the whole issue of taxation and I would like to make some more specific points about the taxation regime as it applies to offshore banking units.

SPEECH.PARA: Since March 1983 and the election of the Hawke Government, the Australian Labor Party in Government has done a large number of things which, when one looks at them conceptually, one sees concentrate power in the hands of fewer and fewer community groups and individuals. We can see from many measures of this Government in a whole range of policies that they have concentrated power more in the hands of what is broadly described as government, meaning politicians and bureaucrats. They have concentrated more power in the hands of the trade union movement. They have even concentrated more power into the hands of a small number of chosen business leaders who want some sort of special privilege in their operation within the marketplace. The consequence of this approach of the Labor Government, which may be convenient to it politically and electorally, is that it has taken away, very substantially, power from the hands of ordinary Australian individuals. When people say that the Labor Government has lost touch, what they are really effectively saying is that the Labor Government is increasingly taking decision-making out of the hands of individuals and putting it increasingly into the hands of the chosen few-those chosen by the Government. The Government's taxation policies since 1983 have been a very clear manifestation of that underlying philosophy.

When one introduces tax policies-and the Government claims that it has introduced a range of taxation reforms-one should have some very simple and very clear objectives. Obviously, for a whole variety of reasons, a government needs to raise revenue. But it needs to do so in a way which, as economists would put it, is essentially neutral-in a way that will allow economic growth to progress, not in a way which distorts growth and minimises the performance of the economy. Of course, we do not just want to maximise the performance of the economy for some abstract reason. We want to maximise the performance of the economy because we want to give individuals within society a greater range of choices. With economic growth and economic success we are going to have greater prosperity and, through greater prosperity, all Australians, not just a few rich people, are going to have greater choices. That should be one of the approaches that any government adopts when establishing its attitudes to and policies on taxation.

For the Labor Party, in very stark contrast to the Liberal Party of Australia, taxation is really a tool of redistribution-not a romantic tool that redistributes wealth from the rich to the poor, as the Labor Party would have us believe, but, as I have already said, a tool which redistributes from ordinary individuals to the Government. In other words, the Labor Party concentrates economic power in the hands of a few and takes it away from individuals.

One should not look at the Government's taxation record just in terms of such political rhetoric as, `Oh, isn't it awful that taxation has increased'. One should do so in the context of what effect that has on the decision-making capacities of individual people. By increasing the tax burden on families and individuals, the Government is confiscating funds from those people and spending them itself rather than allowing individuals to make decisions. As a matter of philosophy, I think that is fundamentally unsound. When one looks at the statistics, one can see how that attitude has been executed by this Government.

Let us take a single income family on average weekly earnings. The average tax rate that that family paid in March 1983 when the Fraser Government was defeated was 17 1/2 per cent. By July 1987 it was 20 1/2 per cent. The Government's marginal tax rate has gone up from 30 per cent to 40 per cent. In numerical terms, tax payments have gone up from $65 a week in March 1983 to $102 a week in July 1987. Even after the latest tax cuts, single income earners and families will be paying 42 per cent and 57 per cent respectively more tax then when the Labor Government came to power. That is a very clear, albeit rather cold and statistical, demonstration of what has happened to choices that individuals might otherwise have been able to make.

When one looks at the company rate structure-and one of the Bills which we are debating tonight relates very specifically to that structure-one can see again that the passion for redistribution in favour always of government is duplicated on top of the taxes that are imposed on individuals. As everybody by now knows, the Government has introduced a whole range of new taxes. It has introduced the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and foreign tax credits scheme, which is a real imposition on Australian companies which also happen to operate offshore. The Government has abolished the investment allowance which was introduced by the Fraser Government. It has also increased the company tax rate in Australia from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. As many other speakers in this debate have said, it has done that in defiance of a global trend. In the United States the company tax rate is now 34 per cent. In Canada it is down to 28 per cent. For small businesses in Canada, that company tax rate has been reduced to 12 per cent and for manufacturing industry it is 21 per cent. In New Zealand, as we all know, the company tax rate is to be reduced to 28 per cent. In Singapore it is 33 per cent while in Hong Kong it is 18 per cent. I could go on and on. In the United Kingdom it is 35 per cent. But in Australia it has gone from 46 per cent to 49 per cent.

When Australia has a staggering balance of payments problem, which the Government acknowledges, and when we have a tremendous challenge to make ourselves more competitive in the world, why is it that we are increasing company taxes from 46 per cent to 49 per cent while the rest of the world is substantially reducing them? The answer is that the Government has effectively admitted that it has made a major mistake. In recent statements the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have said, `We'll have a review of company tax. We had a tax summit, White Papers and so on, and now, a couple of years later, we're suddenly to have a review of the company tax structure and since the New South Wales election happens to be on and the Labor Party is miles behind in the opinion polls let's throw in the prospect that there might also be personal income tax cuts as well.' This is hardly the policy of a sincere government with a great sense of direction, building towards a vision of the future for Australia. It is an utter fraud. After all, during the July 1987 election campaign the Treasurer and the Prime Minister argued, when the Opposition put forward very constructive tax reform proposals, that tax cuts were effectively impossible. They said that it would be far too expensive to reduce taxation in Australia over the next one, two or three years.

Another very interesting argument was put forward then by the Labor Party. That argument was strongly supported by journalist Maximilian Walsh, who, I seem to recall, revealed his political colours on election night. The argument was that if one were to reduce taxation in Australia, the effect would be to create a balance of payments crisis. What has happened? The New South Wales election has come along, the opinion polls do not look too bright for the Australian Labor Party, Ministers are resigning and chaos is reigning within the Government. But the opinion polls show something else-not just that Labor is dropping off, but that tax cuts would be popular and that ordinary Australians-those people who are forgotten by the Labor Party-are crying out for some sort of tax relief to give themselves greater choices rather than having their own money effectively confiscated and spent for them by a paternalistic government.

The Government talks about some sort of tax cuts, but these would have to be massive to restore living standards to the levels they were at when Labor came to power in March 1983. Honourable members can rest assured that such tax cuts will never eventuate. It is all part of the sort of cynical New South Wales Right game that is played by the Hawke Labor Government-number crunching by Senator Graham Richardson, Senator Robert Ray and all of those sorts of people, opinion poll gazing hour after hour, stamping on any dissident views in the media or wherever they may be, making sure that it wins elections at any cost. The fact is that the Government has imposed massive additional tax burdens on Australians and it is far too late now, having decried the idea of tax cuts during the July 1987 election, to say, `Actually, we've just found a few dollars under the table and we've decided there might be some tax cuts'. Do not worry; no one in Australia believes that sort of nonsense any more. We have heard those sorts of things too often and for the Labor Party it is too late.

Let me turn to a more positive aspect of what this debate is all about. I welcome one of the Bills that has been introduced tonight-the Income Tax (Offshore Banking Units) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1987. To use a tired old cliche, it is too little, too late. Nevertheless, I am glad to see that the Government has at least addressed the issue of the need to attract offshore banking units to Australia. As I will explain a little later, we have enormous potential to develop a brand new industry in Australia in that field. I remember that in January 1984 the Whitlam report came out. That was the report of a committee that was chaired by my friend Nick Whitlam. In spite of Nick Whitlam's political leanings, it was a visionary report which came to some very constructive conclusions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who commissioned it?

—Funnily enough, it was the Wran Government that commissioned the report, but interestingly enough, the Unsworth Government has completely ignored and forgotten it. We all know that the only thing it is interested in is opinion polls. As I will explain, the Hawke Labor Government has also almost forgotten it. In relation to the setting up of offshore banking units in Australia, the Hawke Labor Government has done much too little far too late. I think there is an enormous opportunity but the longer we delay the more we will lose that opportunity to establish our country as a regional financial centre. We have really lost that opportunity. The Whitlam report explained how Australia could be established as a financial centre. It said that if we were to develop offshore banking units in Australia we could, in Sydney alone, create 3,500 new jobs. The Federal and State governments, ever voracious for more tax revenue under Labor regimes, could generate an extra $112m a year in tax revenue. That was in 1984 so the figures, presumably, would be substantially higher than that now.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is ideally placed to become a regional financial centre. Yet at the moment there is almost no offshore business conducted in Australia. It is interesting to see that this particular measure introduced tonight by the Government will cost it only one and a half million dollars in lost revenue. That is actually a reflection of how ineffectual offshore banking activity in Australia is at the moment. But we are ideally placed to develop an offshore banking industry and to develop ourselves, through that, as a major financial centre, not only in our region but also-looking into the future-perhaps even globally. We have certain intrinsic advantages. Even with Labor governments we have relative political stability compared with other countries, regardless of the number of resignations from the Labor Government of late. The Asia-Pacific region in which we are inevitably located has enormous growth potential. I think most, if not all, members of this House would agree that this is the great growth region of the world for the next few decades.

We also have some very substantial time zone advantages. For example, Sydney is two or three hours ahead of Singapore and when one travels across the continent to Perth one finds that Perth has a time zone that overlaps quite conveniently with Bahrein and subsequently London. As the Whitlam report put it, because of its location in the world's time zones, Australia can straddle the world. Sydney, as I understand it, has roughly the same time zone as Japan and Japan will be, during the next 10 or 20 years, one of the two major financial centres of the world-surely very soon to overhaul London and challenge New York. Australia is also the host to an enormous amount of British and American capital, so it is not surprising that, given that Australians speak the same language as the Americans and British and that Australia is in the same time zone as Tokyo, there would be a natural inclination for people from New York and London financial centres to operate through Sydney, but only if we had an effective offshore banking system in this country.

The Whitlam report identified two major steps that would be needed if we were to achieve that. First of all, it stated that we ought to set up in Australia a proper surveillance framework so as to ensure that special concessions that would be necessary for offshore banking units would not be used as a means of tax avoidance and tax evasion through artificial paper shuffling. That is not something that the Government has even considered, but I suggest that it should look into it. Secondly, the Whitlam report made it clear that Australia's taxes and other charges would have to be competitive. We are getting back to a rather familiar theme made by the Whitlam report. The son of the famous Gough Whitlam made this point, and, of course, the Whitlam report identified that at that time-and things have got worse since-our taxes and charges were not competitive. The Whitlam report pointed out that the Federal Government should exempt offshore transactions from withholding tax. That is what this legislation has done and it is a good thing. But Australia should also introduce a much more competitive company tax regime. I have been through the arguments about how company tax has been rising in Australia and falling in other countries. But let me remind the House that in Singapore offshore banking units are paying a company tax rate of 10 per cent. In Australia they would pay a company tax rate of 49 per cent, hardly a basis for a competitive offshore banking system in this country. As the Whitlam report pointed out, it is better to have 10 per cent of something than 46 per cent-as it was then-of nothing. That is a very important point and one that I hope the Government will take proper notice of.

There are things the Whitlam report recommended that State governments should do as well. It suggested, and perhaps this is a little too dramatic, that voracious, tax hungry governments such as the Unsworth Government should exempt offshore banking units from stamp duties and financial institutions duties. This might be an opportunity for the Bannon Government in South Australia to do something to give South Australia the inside edge at least on one industry somewhere around Australia. But unfortunately that is hoping for far too much. The Whitlam report recommended that those things should be done by the States as well. Needless to say they have not been done.

In conclusion, as I have said, Australia ought to be looking progressively at the sorts of things it can do to make itself, at least at this stage, a significant financial centre in its region and, in the longer term, a major global financial centre. This will have obvious economic spin-offs. It will generate additional tax revenues for governments that love all that extra tax revenue. It will generate additional jobs in Australia and, through the offshore banking system, it will generate additional prosperity for all Australians. That must be not our only objective but one of our major objectives as members of parliament.

If we are to achieve these sorts of things, if we are to get some of the business that at the moment is going almost exclusively to places such as Tokyo and Singapore, we need to look ahead. We need to think big. We cannot continue to be strangled by Labor's quite extraordinary taxation regime. We have to ensure that we have a tax structure which shows that as a nation we have some ambitions for building ourselves up in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have suffered another lecture from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) on taxation. The Liberal Party, or sections of it, have more front than a double decker bus getting up here in this place and telling us about taxation--
—He would keep a hot air balloon afloat.

—As my colleague says, the honourable member could keep a hot air balloon afloat just on what he said tonight. Given the Liberal Party's record on taxation, for the honourable member to get up here and lecture us on how we should run a tax regime is stretching credibility to the limit. Let us look at the sort of taxation regime the Liberal Party ran. Let us recall 1982 and 1983, the infamous bottom of the harbour days, when we really found out how good the Liberals were at administering the taxation system of this country. It was a case of freedom of choice for some people-usually the more affluent-as to whether they paid tax or not.
—Those schemes were under the Whitlam Government.

—The question I would ask the honourable member who interjects is what did Mr Howard do about the schemes? He sat there and had to be dragged screaming in here to outlaw them retrospectively. He sat there for three years while nothing was done by the Treasurer of the day, even though the Commissioner of Taxation tried to get him to do something about it. We remember that under the Liberal regime the more affluent were able to book up their free lunches to the taxpayers. We remember the cars, the low interest loans, the overseas trips. All of those rorts were built into the taxation system and kept there by the Liberal Party.
—They want to give them back.

—Yes. The Leader of the Opposition went to the people in July on the theme `Axe the tax', giving back all the benefits to the people who took advantage of them under the previous regime, the people from the big end of town. The honourable member for Mayo also spoke of high taxation. It is always salutary to look at the graph put out by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) by which one can compare the taxation collections-these are the latest available statistics-in the OECD countries. Of the 23 countries in the OECD, Australia comes eighteenth. In fact, we are not a high taxing country at all. What the honourable member for Mayo, who is now leaving the chamber, would have us believe is that we should be looking at Turkey. Turkey has the lowest tax collection as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP).
—Speaking of turkey--

—The honourable member is a little unkind, but I shall continue. Turkey collects the smallest amount of taxes as a percentage of GDP, and it could be said, `Maybe we should be like Turkey and collect that amount of tax as well'. But the downside of that argument is that if one wants Turkey's tax rates, one will get Turkey's social security provisions. If one gets Turkey's tax rates, one will also get Turkey's law and order provisions. The fact is that if one does not collect the tax, one cannot spend it. In recent days the Leader of the Opposition has spoken about going back to the spending patterns of the 1960s, cutting $11,000m off tax and bringing back the tax rorts. That is the system suggested by the Opposition, which seeks to lecture the Labor Government on what we are doing on tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is saying that a high taxing Labor Government is spending all this taxpayers' money on the necessary things on which taxes are spent. I refer to expenditure on roads, education, pensions and the running of government. This includes the employment of civil servants to keep this country running, expenditure on the defence forces, and all the necessary infrastructure which gives Australia the high standard of living that it enjoys. That is why we collect the taxes. We are not a high taxing country, but we have a high standard of living. One can draw a direct correlation with countries that do not have a high standard of living. In regard to the Third World, one could say that Bangladesh, for example, does not collect a high percentage of its GDP in taxes, but look at its standard of living. The countries that collect a high percentage of their GDP in taxes are countries with a high standard of living. For example, the OECD chart shows that Sweden is the highest taxing country. Over 50 per cent of its GDP is in the form of taxes. Yet would any honourable member seriously suggest that Sweden, because it collects all those taxes, is somehow a country that is going backwards? We are building Swedish submarines down in Adelaide. It seems to me that Sweden is doing pretty well in this world. Despite the amount of taxes it collects, Sweden can still run an industry that is very export oriented and highly technological in its outlook. Certainly it is a country with which we compare ourselves.

The honourable member for Mayo says that we are a high taxing country and should lower taxes. He believes that we should start getting into a Mad Hatter's auction to see who can achieve the lowest tax rate. If we really want Bangladeshi taxes, we will get Bangladeshi social security provisions. The choice is obvious. It is a bit much to be lectured in this place by a Liberal member about the efficacy of taxation collections, and the way in which this Government has moved to make sure that taxes are appropriate in terms of not only what we collect but also where we collect them from. This Government has patched up all the holes in the sloppy taxation system which the Liberal Government ran for so many years. The withholding tax brought in by this Government was fought by the Opposition. When this Government tried to get back the proceeds from the bottom of the harbour rorts, again the Opposition opposed that move. One will always remember the capital gains debate. The debate on that subject was never of any value because it was always debased by the Liberal Party's scare campaign. Yet I notice in the Australian Financial Review that the capital gains tax will lead to the collection of taxes of the order of $1,000m directly and indirectly. That is a measure of the taxation that was slipping through the net because we did not have an effective capital gains tax. What would the Opposition do? The Opposition would take that out and the ordinary taxpayer would have to subsidise $1,000m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Video Violence-Toy Weapons-Allegations by Mr P. Sawyer-Sales Tax Exemption Form-Mrs Kerry Anne Aitken-Northern Territory: Teachers-Health Insurance Commission

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, tonight I want to address the subject of video violence. Violence in any form encourages violence in itself and it should be of great concern to members of this House that if we continue to bring our children up on a diet of television and video violence and films which glorify war and glamorise murder, we run the very real risk of producing a generation which takes violence, murder and mayhem for granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Worldwide research undertaken by psychologists studying video and movie violence proves unequivocally that the amount of violence on the screen does affect the amount of violence in society. The average child watches 25 hours of television a week, spends a growing number of hours watching videos and on average sees one movie per week in a cinema. What the viewer learns in many cases from violent movies, either consciously or not, is that violence resolves conflict. This a frightening trend in what is supposed to be an entertainment medium.

The Australian Psychologists Society has called for a reduction in excessive violence in the media and has warned parents to monitor their children's viewing patterns. It is the responsibility of parents to teach their children that there are methods of solving conflict other than resorting to violence. I am pleased to say that Australian Psychologists Society also has appealed to the film and television industry to regulate and reduce the amount of violence shown on their screens.

Parents' responsibility also extends to the toys they buy for their children. The manufacture of toy weapons has become so sophisticated that there are many cases on record of toy weapons being used in robberies. Replicas of semi-automatic weapons, high-powered repeater guns and their ilk should be banned from sale. I am particularly pleased to learn that in some centres the message of toys of violence encouraging violence has been felt by supermarkets carrying such items. I am aware that one K-Mart store, for example, which stocks toy guns ranging from cap pistols, Zappit guns, rapid-fire hand guns, to semi-automatic M16s-that is, machine guns-have sold only half a dozen items since Christmas. Business is so slow in this particular area that some of the toy guns have been reduced in price by almost 50 per cent to try to clear them. I am told this a very different position from that of a year ago.

Society is beginning to react adversely to the sale of such toys. Community concern over the new gun laws has obviously had an effect on the sale of toy guns. There is on the market a laser gun. This shoots a laser beam at a target wearing a special material and when hit the target emits a beep. This toy-and I hesitate to call it a toy-teaches children to target more accurately another human being. They get a result. They see where they have hit the other person. The next step is a real weapon with real ammunition

From the age of five, children who have access to many hours of television viewing and videos are exposed to the influence of lethal weapons and toy replicas are used at home to simulate violence, murder and killing. I am not suggesting that all who are exposed to toys of violence are so easily influenced, but there is irrefutable evidence that some viewers are more vulnerable than others. I would like to see all toy weapons banned for the reasons I have outlined. I repeat that violence encourages violence.

The most popular videos are violent videos. One proprietor told me that it was impossible to view every film handled and he relied on customer reports and censorship classification. In fact, proprietors concerned at the amount of violence have imposed their own censorship by placing warnings on the covers. A study conducted by the Australian Institute of Criminology to examine sex, violence and sexual violence in popular M-rated and R-rated videos concluded that X-rated sex films were less harmful to society than violent R-rated and M-rated videos and recommended that videos should have more information on their jackets about the severity of the scenes. The study advocated subsections within the R-rated category. I conclude by quoting comments from one member of the study team:

Some videos attempted to show viewers that it is correct to take the law into their own hands and that any level of revenge . . . is right. It is this combination of violence and attempted justification of such aggression that disturbs me most. If viewers are influenced by what they watch, then these movies could trigger some violent acts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make a few comments on a man called Peter Sawyer who first came to fame because he published a book called Dolebludging: A Taxpayer's Guide. Mr Sawyer has recently gained renown for producing a newsletter called Inside News which has been circulated to a number of honourable members. Inside News has made a number of claims which are quite laughable. I wish to explain them in detail to the House, not to get a laugh but to explain why this material is quite dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Sawyer has claimed that the Government has established a super concrete fortress at the Deakin telephone exchange in Canberra. At that exchange, Mr Sawyer claims, billions of dollars have illegally been diverted to allow a top secret group to establish computer hardware in which all sorts of information on Australian citizens is being built up and that this is part of a conspiracy directed by, according to Mr Sawyer, not only the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Gareth Evans but also Senator John Stone, John Elliott, Alan Jones, Charles Copeman and numerous other people. Mr Sawyer goes on to allege that another group, a group he calls `a secret society of Australian dentists' called Delta Sigma Delta is also part of this conspiracy to take over the Australian Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The drillers.

—The drillers, perhaps, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory suggests. While allegations such as this are quite ridiculous, it is very hard to disprove a story which is as wild as that put forward by Mr Sawyer. It will be no surprise that Mr Sawyer believes that, as part of this conspiracy, and I quote from his newsletter:

SPEECH.PARA: Ultimately, all roads appear to lead back to international banking institutions, principally the Rothchilds and the Rockefellers.

There is another case going back to the alleged international Jewish conspiracy. It is no surprise that the League of Rights appears to be trying to jump aboard this bandwagon and seek to mislead some people who perhaps for genuine reasons believe there is a particular problem with new technology. These people are given these ridiculous stories by people such as Mr Sawyer. They perhaps sign a letter or a petition and the League of Rights gets their name and address and they suddenly start receiving League of Rights material promoting anti-semitic propa- ganda. I think that is quite unfortunate.

Mr Sawyer's other allegations are that at the Deakin telephone exchange-this fortress building-there are stand-by diesel generators, which is quite true, and that there is food accommodation for staff for eight weeks. I and other members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts were able to inspect the Deakin telephone exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pretty easy to fool though.

—The interjection from the honourable member for Gippsland is no reflection on the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) who accompanied us on that inspection. As I said, one of Mr Sawyer's allegations is that there is enough food accommodation in the basement of the Deakin telephone exchange to support the staff for eight weeks. We found out that the only food on the premises is the food in the canteen and claims that that would support the staff for eight weeks is drawing a very long bow. He claimed that there were computers there for the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Defence, the Department of Transport and Communications and Telecom Australia, and that is true. But he also wrongly alleged that the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the Department of Community Services and Health and Australia Post had computer hardware there. That is plain wrong. He also alleges that the State governments put land titles and car registration information there and that the exchange is also hooked up to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the American strategic defence network, which is also utterly ridiculous.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to draw to the attention of the House that Mr Sawyer has asked many people to send cheques made out to cash, uncrossed, to his post office box address. On my calculations he has received more than $10,000 tax free. I call on the Commissioner of Taxation to investigate Mr Sawyer and what has happened to the more than $10,000 which has been sent to him. It is about time that Mr Sawyer came clean and told us what he has been doing with all the money which some people have been sending to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to raise something related to the Australian Taxation Office, as did the honour- able member for Dobell (Mr Lee). But the matter I want to raise is somewhat different. When Senator Stone pulled the rug from under the identity card all of us on this side of the House, and many on the other side of the House, breathed a huge sigh of relief. Many of us thought that at long last commonsense had prevailed and we would not have to put up with the gross invasion of privacy that would have come with the ID card proposal that some members of the Government were rather keen to push.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, it seems that the bureaucracy, and particularly the Australian Taxation Office, did not hear about that. I want to raise a matter that was brought to my attention by a constituent who happened to go to buy a four wheel drive vehicle for his farm. As honourable members would be aware, farmers are allowed an exemption from sales tax on four wheel drive vehicles. When this farmer went to buy the vehicle, he was not confronted with the old form which used to cover about half a page and which said, `Are you a primary producer' to which the answer was, `Yes, I am, and I am going to use this vehicle on my property located at so and so'-and that was all there was to it. Since most farmers are completely honest I think that that was a perfectly reasonable form to ask them to sign. But that does not happen any more.

It seems that under the new proposals, the Australian Taxation Office has replaced a simple half-page exemption form with a three-page monster. In this three-page monster, the questions asked are a gross invasion of privacy. The first page starts off fairly innocently with such questions as, `Name', `Residential address' and `Contact telephone No.' Question No. 4 concerns previous exemption applications that have been put in and when and where they were lodged. Then details have to be given of the vehicle to be purchased. That is fair enough. Question 6 asks whether the vehicle is a replacement vehicle and whether the previous vehicle was also free of tax-and, if so, it requires details. Again, that is maybe not too intrusive. Question 7 asks for the income tax file number. Since honourable members on this side of the chamber and many opposite were prepared to accept that the income tax file number would be a suitable alternative to an ID card, I guess this is a reasonable request. We go on to question 8, `For what purpose(s) will the vehicle be used?'. That should be obvious. The last question is, `Item number under which exemption is claimed'. All that is fine.

Then we turn over to part B on page 2. Question 1 is `Size of property'; question 2 is `Location of property'; question 3 is `Gross income from agricultural activities declared in last Income Tax return'. We have seen that there is a request for the income tax file number but now the person must also declare his gross income in case there is a difference. Question 4 is `Date agricultural activities commenced'. Question 5-and we are getting into a bit more detail-is `Type of crop and area under cultivation'. Question 6-just to make sure people are tied up properly-is `Number, and type, of livestock raised'. Question 7 is `If this is the first year agricultural activities are being undertaken, what are the answers to the previous questions, and any other information?'.

By any measure, this is going into far more details of a personal nature than even an income tax form does. It is a gross invasion of privacy and is totally unnecessary. I would like to see the Treasurer (Mr Keating) demand that the Australian Taxation Office desist from issuing this form, simplify it, take out the questions that are a gross invasion of privacy and bring it back to what is a reasonable request, `Are you, or are you not, eligible for a sales tax exemption?'. Since time is running out, I seek leave to table a copy of this sales tax form so that honourable members can see what is involved.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This really amounts to a gross invasion of privacy. Much of this information is totally unnecessary. Asking for an income tax file number should allow all the questions about whether a person is a genuine primary producer to be answered. The Treasurer should take up this case immediately and direct the Taxation Office to simplify this form, take out these questions and bring it back to something sensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to inform the House of the extraordinary act of bravery and self-sacrifice made by a teacher in the Northern Territory Teaching Service-a teacher at Sanderson High School in Darwin. The teacher was Mrs Kerry Anne Aitken, who returned to school this morning. I wish to take this opportunity to tell the House about her extraordinary bravery. I refer to an article headlined `Classroom horror as school opens' which appeared in the Northern Territory News on 28 January. On that day, Mrs Kerry Anne Aitken, a senior home economics teacher, was taken by ambulance to the Royal Darwin Hospital where she underwent surgery for abdominal wounds caused by gunshot. Those gunshot wounds were inflicted by her husband, who later turned the gun on himself. That person arrived at the school at 9 a.m. and walked through three classrooms firing gunshots into the ceiling. Mrs Aitken, who was taking a textile class, saw him coming and beckoned him to a classroom and then an adjoining storeroom. It was in that storeroom that Mr Aitken turned the gun on Mrs Aitken and shot her. In my view, and that of the population of the Northern Territory, Mrs Aitken has shown an extraordinary dedication to her duty as a teacher and to the students for whom she is responsible. She is a very popular member of the school community and her bravery following that horrific incident has been admired by people throughout the Northern Territory. It is not uncommon--
—Order! Can the honourable member inform the Chair whether this case is proceeding before a court?
—No. The person has passed away. I apologise, Madam Speaker: I should have made that clear.
—We do not want to infringe the sub judice rule if a court case is going on.

—I appreciate that, Madam Speaker. Mrs Kerry Anne Aitken typifies the dedication of teachers who work in the Northern Territory Teaching Service. I was a member of that Teaching Service. I am very proud of the way in which the dedication of teachers is exhibited as they carry out their duties. Unfortunately, the Northern Territory Government chose recently to have an all-out attack on the school community in the Northern Territory, particularly the teachers. Recently it introduced amendments to regulations to change the nature of school councils in the Northern Territory. The effect was to restrict the number of teachers, whether those teachers be parents of members of the school community, who can belong to the councils. The Northern Territory Government has introduced changes to the regulations, making it impossible for more than one-third of the representative number of school council members to be members of the Education Department. In other words, if the parent of a child at a school seeks representation on a school council and he or she is a teacher at another school, and if the membership of the school council is nine people, for example, of whom three members are teachers from within the school, that parent is denied the opportunity to be a member of that school council.

SPEECH.PARA: That is being done partly because the Northern Territory Government says that the school community in the Northern Territory is not being well serviced by teachers because they are too political. The problem is that the Northern Territory Government is attacking the Teaching Service in the Northern Territory and the teachers. It regards them as too political because they are not prepared to accept the rot that the Northern Territory Education Minister has been handing down to them. They have reacted to the way in which their conditions have gradually been attacked over the past 12 to 18 months by the Northern Territory Government and they are not prepared to accept the attacks on the standards of education that have been forthcoming as a result of the Northern Territory Government's policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to return to an issue that I first raised on the adjournment yesterday evening, and that is the twin problem of, firstly, the favoured commercial advantages that Medibank Private enjoys under this Government and, secondly, the termination of private health fund agencies for Medicare. The Opposition has long believed that Medibank Private is better treated by the Government than private health funds, and now the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia Ltd has commissioned Touche Ross, a reputable firm of chartered accountants, to settle the issue once and for all. Its report found that Medibank Private enjoys a great many advantages over the private health funds. I understand that, in response, the Minister has commissioned Price Waterhouse, chartered accountants, to reply to the report of Touche Ross.

SPEECH.PARA: Until the issue is definitively settled, I call upon the Government, as have the private health funds already, to provide a three months delay in the termination of the private health funds agency agreements. Only then will the Government be able to make the correct fiscal decision on whether terminating the agencies will save $1.5m in a full year, as the Health Insurance Commission would have us believe. I do not believe that that figure can be substantiated.

Medibank Private enjoys a tremendous advantage over private health funds because of its linkage with Medicare, and its membership is increasing dramatically while the membership of private health funds is rapidly decreasing. Medibank Private shares offices with Medicare across the country. Therefore, acting as an agency for Medicare it has a ready-made audience. Medicare takes care of the hospital benefits and Medibank Private can sell its medical benefits. There is also cost sharing with Medicare in the offices, and Medibank Private offers one-stop shopping in the same offices, and that gives it a tremendous advantage over private health funds, which must establish offices for themselves.

The most telling point is that Medibank Private has 290 branches throughout Australia to deal with 25 per cent of the claims under Medicare. The remaining 75 per cent are bulkbilled. So Medicare has 290 officers to cope with only 25 per cent of the accounts. If Medibank Private were made to operate as a free-standing fund, it could not survive. No fund could survive with 290 branches throughout Australia. However, Medibank Private flourishes by sharing offices with Medicare.

There is no doubt that the Health Insurance Commission is misleading the Government by stating that the termination of the agencies will save the Government $1.5m. I addressed that issue at length last night so there is no need for me to go over old ground. It is essential that the Treasury and the Department of Finance again go over the figures supplied by the Health Insurance Commission, particularly in the light of the report by Touche Ross. Unless there is a three-month extension of the termination of the agencies, the matter cannot be cleared up in time. After all, is it not in the Government's interests to consider the response of Price Waterhouse commissioned by the Government?

The Health Insurance Commission operates Medibank Private in a very profit-oriented sense. That is fine; so all government agencies or instrumentalities should have the same profit mentality and profit ethic, so long as they do not have unfair and almost incalculable advantages over competitors from the private sector. That is the crux of the complaint. I want Medibank Private to be as aggressive and profitable as it possibly can be but not when it enjoys so many commercial advantages over the private sector. The truth is that the private health funds in this country are bleeding to death and this Government is standing idly by.
